[[Image:Muh-hund-original-rondellliten.JPG|thumb|right|Image by Lars Vilks published in ''Nerikes Allehanda'' adjacent to the editorial]] The '''Lars Vilks Muhammad drawings controversy''' began in July 2007 with a series of [[drawing]]s by Swedish artist [[Lars Vilks]] that depicted the [[Islam]]ic prophet [[Muhammad]] as a [[roundabout dog]] (a form of [[street installation]] in Sweden). Several art galleries in Sweden declined to show the drawings, citing security concerns and fear of violence. The controversy gained international attention after the [[Örebro]]-based regional newspaper ''[[Nerikes Allehanda]]'' published one of the drawings on 18 August as part of an [[editorial]] on [[self-censorship]] and [[freedom of religion]].{{cite news |first=Lars |last=Ströman |title=Rätten att förlöjliga en religion |url=http://www.na.se/artikel.asp?intId=1209627 |publisher=[[Nerikes Allehanda]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-08-18 |accessdate=2007-08-31 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070906190721/http://www.na.se/artikel.asp?intId=1209627 |archivedate = 2007-09-06}}
English translation: {{cite news |first=Lars |last=Ströman |title=The right to ridicule a religion |url=http://www.na.se/artikel.asp?intId=1209676 |publisher=[[Nerikes Allehanda]] |date=2007-08-28 |accessdate=2007-08-31 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070830163657/http://www.na.se/artikel.asp?intId=1209676 |archivedate = 2007-08-30}} While several other leading Swedish newspapers had published the drawings already, this particular publication led to protests from Muslims in Sweden as well as official condemnations from several foreign governments including [[Iran]],{{cite news|title=Iran protests over Swedish Muhammad cartoon |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8305/20070827/ |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=2007-08-27 |accessdate=2007-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070829141345/http://www.thelocal.se/8305/20070827/ |archivedate=2007-08-29 |df= }} [[Pakistan]],{{cite press release|title=PAKISTAN CONDEMNS THE PUBLICATION OF OFFENSIVE SKETCH IN SWEDEN |publisher=[[Pakistan Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] |date=2007-08-30 |url=http://www.mofa.gov.pk/Press_Releases/2007/Aug/PR_234_07.htm |accessdate=2007-08-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070904154021/http://www.mofa.gov.pk/Press_Releases/2007/Aug/PR_234_07.htm |archivedate=2007-09-04 |df= }} [[Afghanistan]],{{cite news |first=Sayed |last=Salahuddin |title=Indignant Afghanistan slams Prophet Mohammad sketch |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/SouthAsiaNews/idINIndia-29281220070901 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=2007-09-01 |accessdate=2007-09-09}} [[Egypt]],{{cite news |first=Gwladys |last=Fouché |title=Egypt wades into Swedish cartoons row |url=http://media.guardian.co.uk/presspublishing/story/0,,2161595,00.html |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=2007-09-03 |accessdate=2007-09-09}} and [[Jordan]],{{cite news |title=Jordan condemns new Swedish Mohammed cartoon |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20070903/wl_mideast_afp/jordanswedenislam_070903124623 |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=2007-09-03 |accessdate=2007-09-09}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} as well as by the inter-governmental [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|Organisation of the Islamic Conference]] (OIC).{{cite press release|title=The Secretary General strongly condemned the publishing of blasphemous caricatures of Prophet Muhammad by Swedish artist |publisher=[[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|Organisation of the Islamic Conference]] |date=2007-08-30 |url=http://www.oic-oci.org/press/English/2007/08/caricatur.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012054243/http://oic-oci.org/press/English/2007/08/caricatur.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-10-12 |accessdate=2007-09-09 |df= }} The controversy occurred about a year and a half after the [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy|''Jyllands-Posten'' Muhammad cartoons controversy]] in Denmark in early 2006. == Background == [[Image:Lars Vilks 20050722.jpg|thumb|right|[[Lars Vilks]]]] On 11 June 2007, Vilks was invited to participate in an art exhibition on the theme "The Dog in Art" ({{lang-sv|Hunden i konsten}}) that was to be held in the small town of [[Tällerud]] in [[Värmland]]. Vilks submitted three [[pen]] and [[ink]] [[drawing]]s on [[ISO 216|A4 paper]] depicting [[Muhammad]] as a [[roundabout dog]]. At this time, Vilks was already participating with drawings of Muhammad in another exhibition in [[Vestfossen]], Norway, on the theme "Oh, My God". Vilks, who is a known proponent of [[institutional art]], has stated that his original intention with the drawings was to "examine the [[political correctness]] within the boundaries of the art community".{{cite episode |title=Argument 6 september 2007 : Debatt om Yttrandefrihet |episodelink= |series=Argument |serieslink=Argument (television program) |credits= |network=[[Sveriges Television]] |station=[[SVT1]] |airdate=2007-09-06 |season=2 |number=1 |minutes= }} According to Vilks, the art and culture communities in Sweden repeatedly criticize the United States and [[Israel]], whereas Muslim values are rarely even questioned.{{cite news|title=Islamists push for boycott of Swedish firms |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8542/20070919/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-09-19 |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071028162633/http://www.thelocal.se/8542/20070919/ |archivedate=2007-10-28 |df= }} On 20 July, the day before the opening of the exhibition in Tällerud, the organizers decided to withdraw Vilks's drawings from the exhibition due to security concerns and fear of violence from [[Islamic extremism|Islamic extremists]] (''see [[Islam and blasphemy]] and [[Islam and animals]]''). Märta Wennerström, the exhibition's organizer, said that at first she "didn't realize the gravity of the situation" and that she made the decision to remove the drawings after consulting [[Government agencies in Sweden|Swedish government agencies]] and private persons.{{cite news|title=Muhammed som rondellhund stoppas |url=http://www.nwt.se/ArticlePages/200707/20/20070720205557_NWT845/20070720205557_NWT845.dbp.asp |publisher=[[Nya Wermlands-Tidningen]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-07-20 |accessdate=2007-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823022045/http://www.nwt.se/ArticlePages/200707/20/20070720205557_NWT845/20070720205557_NWT845.dbp.asp |archivedate=2007-08-23 |df= }}{{cite news |first=Bosse |last=Brink |title=Teckningar på Muhammed togs bort |url=http://www.svd.se/dynamiskt/inrikes/did_16316985.asp |publisher=[[Svenska Dagbladet]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-07-21 |accessdate=2007-08-27}} Following the first refusal to publish the drawings, Vilks submitted his drawings to the [[Gerlesborg School of Fine Art]] in [[Bohuslän]] (where he is a frequent lecturer) for a special teachers' exhibition that was going to be opened on 18 August. On 13 August, however, the school announced that they also had decided to reject the drawings due to security concerns.{{cite news |first=Johan |last=Sjöstrand |title=Stopp igen för Vilks Muhammed-bilder |url=http://www.svd.se/dynamiskt/kultur/did_16670977.asp |publisher=[[Svenska Dagbladet]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-07-13 |accessdate=2007-08-27}} This second rejection started an intense debate in the Swedish media about [[self-censorship]] and [[freedom of expression]]. On 18 August, the [[Örebro]]-based regional newspaper ''[[Nerikes Allehanda]]'' published one of Vilks's drawings in an [[editorial]] on freedom of expression. The editorial defended "Muslims' right to freedom of religion" but also said it must be permitted to "ridicule Islam's most foremost symbols — just like all other religions' symbols." On the same day, the drawings were also published in several other Swedish newspapers including ''[[Aftonbladet]]'', ''[[Dagens Nyheter]]'', ''[[Expressen]]'' and ''[[Upsala Nya Tidning]]''. == Reactions == === International reactions === On 27 August, the Swedish ''[[chargé d'affaires]]'' in [[Tehran]], Gunilla von Bahr, was summoned to the Iranian foreign ministry where she received a protest from the [[Government of Iran|Iranian government]] against the publication in ''Nerikes Allehanda''. On 28 August the [[President of Iran]], [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]], commented on the drawings during a press conference. He was quoted by the [[Islamic Republic News Agency]] as saying: "Religions call for friendship, equality, justice, peace and respect for divine prophets. The Zionists only pretend to believe in religion. They are telling lies. They are perpetrating oppression against the Europeans and putting at risk the prestige of Europe." {{cite news|title=President castigates Swedish daily for publishing blasphemy |url=http://www2.irna.com/en/news/view/line-17/0708280953195316.htm |publisher=[[Islamic Republic News Agency]] |date=2007-08-28 |accessdate=2007-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929091659/http://www2.irna.com/en/news/view/line-17/0708280953195316.htm |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }}{{cite news|title=Ahmadinejad claims 'Zionists' behind Swedish cartoon |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8319/20070828/ |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-08-28 |accessdate=2007-08-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830131140/http://www.thelocal.se/8319/20070828/ |archivedate=2007-08-30 |df= }} On 30 August, the Swedish ''chargé d'affaires'' in [[Islamabad]], Lennart Holst, was summoned to the [[Pakistani Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] to receive a similar protest from the [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistani government]].{{cite news|first=James |last=Savage |title=Muhammad cartoon: Sweden 'sorry for hurt feelings' |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8341/20070830/ |publisher=[[The Local]] |date=2007-08-30 |accessdate=2007-08-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902154003/http://www.thelocal.se/8341/20070830/ |archivedate=2007-09-02 |df= }} The Pakistani Ministry of Foreign Affairs later issued a statement where it condemned the publication "in the strongest terms". On the same day the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|Organisation of the Islamic Conference]] (OIC), an inter-governmental organization which represents 57 Muslim countries, issued a statement where it strongly condemned the publishing of blasphemous caricatures of Muhammad by Swedish artist Lars Vilks in the ''Nerikes Allehanda'' newspaper. The secretary-general of OIC, [[Ekmeleddin İhsanoğlu]], further called on the Swedish government to take "immediate punitive actions against the artist and the publishers of the cartoon and asked for their unqualified apology". On 31 August, supporters from Islamic parties in Pakistan burned the [[Flag of Sweden|Swedish flag]] in the city of [[Lahore]]. In [[Karachi]], others torched an effigy of the [[Swedish Prime Minister]] to protest the cartoon.{{cite news |title=Muslims Protest Swedish Newspaper's Cartoon of Prophet Muhammad |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,295431,00.html |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=2007-08-31 |accessdate=2007-09-10}} On 1 September, the [[Afghanistan|Afghan]] newspaper ''[[Kabul Times]]'' published a statement by religious scholars, imams and the Afghan [[Ministry of Islamic Guidance]]. The statement said that "The sold-out enemies of Islam draw the cartoon of the respected Prophet of Islam once more. This has disturbed the Islamic world and aroused the indignation of all Muslims". The statement demanded those responsible be handed over to a court for prosecution and punishment. On 3 September, the [[Ministry of Awqaf (Egypt)|Egyptian Ministry of Religious Endowments]] condemned the publication, saying that "such an irresponsible act is not conducive to friendly ties between the Islamic world and the west". On the same day, also the [[Government of Jordan|Jordanian government]] condemned the publication. A spokesperson for the government said that "The publication of this cartoon, which seeks to attack the character of the Prophet Mohammed, is unacceptable, rejected and condemned". === Domestic reactions === On 25 August, a group of about 60 Muslims held a demonstration outside ''Nerikes Allehanda'''s office in Örebro to protest against the publication.{{cite news|first=Erik |last=Hedtjärn |title=Demonstration mot Muhammedhundar |url=http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=1058&a=684516 |publisher=[[Dagens Nyheter]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-08-24 |accessdate=2007-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070826215156/http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=1058&a=684516 |archivedate=2007-08-26 |df= }} On 31 August, [[Prime Minister of Sweden|Swedish Prime Minister]] [[Fredrik Reinfeldt]] commented on the issue and said: "I think it's important to say two things. First, we are eager to ensure that Sweden remains a country in which Muslims and Christians, people who believe in God and people who don't believe in God, can live side by side in a spirit of mutual respect [...] We are also eager to stand up for freedom of expression, which is enshrined in the [[Constitution of Sweden|constitution]] and comes naturally to us, and which ensures that we do not make political decisions about what gets published in the newspapers. I want to make sure we keep things that way."{{cite news|title=Reinfeldt speaks out about Muhammad controversy |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8350/20070831/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-08-31 |accessdate=2007-08-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902154105/http://www.thelocal.se/8350/20070831/ |archivedate=2007-09-02 |df= }} The same day, around 300 demonstrators – led by the Islamic Cultural Centre in Örebro – assembled outside the offices of ''Nerikes Allehanda'' to protest against the newspaper's publication.{{cite news|title=Demonstrators in Muhammad picture protest |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8351/20070831/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-08-31 |accessdate=2007-08-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902153815/http://www.thelocal.se/8351/20070831/ |archivedate=2007-09-02 |df= }} On 7 September, Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt met with ambassadors from 22 Muslim countries to discuss the issue. Reinfeldt said that he had "explained how Swedish society works and that we don't have elected representatives making editorial decisions", adding that "this is an open country, a tolerant country".{{cite news|title=Muslim ambassadors 'made no demands' |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8424/20070907/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]]/[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=2007-09-07 |accessdate=2007-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070910191024/http://www.thelocal.se/8424/20070907/ |archivedate=2007-09-10 |df= }} Prior to the meeting, Egyptian ambassador [[Mohamed Sotouhi]] said, according to the news agency [[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå|TT]], that he and a group of fellow ambassadors had agreed on a list of measures that Sweden needed to take and to present it to the Prime Minister. "We want to see action, not just nice words. We have to push for a change in the law", he said.{{cite news|title=Muslim ambassadors: 'Sweden needs to change its laws' |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8412/20070906/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]]/[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=2007-09-06 |accessdate=2007-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070908151322/http://www.thelocal.se/8412/20070906/ |archivedate=2007-09-08 |df= }} After the meeting however, Reinfeldt denied that any such list had been presented to him. According to the [[Syrian Arab News Agency]], a statement had been delivered from the Swedish embassy in [[Damascus]] to Syria's [[Grand Mufti]] [[Ahmad Bader Hassoun]] in which Reinfeldt "expressed his regret of the incident which has offended and upset Muslims, calling against instigating or offending other religions".{{cite news |title=Sweden Apologizes for Newspapers Offending Muslims |url=http://www.sana.org/eng/22/2007/09/05/137784.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308164039/http://sana.org/eng/22/2007/09/05/137784.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2016-03-08 |publisher=[[Syrian Arab News Agency]] |date=2007-09-05 |accessdate=2007-09-12}} The Swedish government has not commented on this statement. [[Image:Muh-hund-originallit.JPG|thumb|right|200px|One of Vilks's original three drawings, depicting [[Muhammad]] as a [[roundabout dog]].]] Also on 7 September, a group of about 550 Muslims gathered outside the offices of the newspaper ''[[Upsala Nya Tidning]]'' in [[Uppsala]], to protest against the newspaper's publication of the cartoons.{{cite news|title=Muhammad cartoons spark new protest |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8428/20070907/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-09-07 |accessdate=2007-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070910031849/http://www.thelocal.se/8428/20070907/ |archivedate=2007-09-10 |df= }} == Threats and attacks == Following the publication in ''Nerikes Allehanda'', the [[Swedish Police Authority|Swedish police]] raised the security level around the newspaper's headquarters and some of its employees have been forced to use bodyguards after receiving death threats. Vilks himself has also received several death threats.{{cite news|first=Erik |last=Scherlund |title=Lars Vilks hotad till livet |url=http://tv4nyheterna.se/1.163969/nyheter/2007/08/31/lars_vilks_hotad_till_livet |publisher=[[TV4Nyheterna]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-08-31 |accessdate=2007-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902105232/http://tv4nyheterna.se/1.163969/nyheter/2007/08/31/lars_vilks_hotad_till_livet |archivedate=2007-09-02 |df= }} One Muslim woman in western Sweden has been arrested on charges of issuing a death threat ({{lang-sv|olaga hot}}) against Vilks in an e-mail. The woman confirmed in police interrogation that she had written the mail and said that she did not have any regrets about it.{{cite news |title=Kvinna delgiven för mordhot av Vilks |url=http://www.svd.se/dynamiskt/inrikes/did_17015499.asp?blogAbuseID=36649 |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-09-05 |accessdate=2007-09-12}} On 6 September, one actual roundabout dog created by Vilks and local children was set alight as an apparent threat.[http://www.thelocal.se/8420/20070907/ The Local – Sculpture by controverial [sic] artist set on fire] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115075921/http://www.thelocal.se/8420/20070907/ |date=November 15, 2007 }} On 15 September, it was reported that the group [[Islamic State of Iraq]] had placed a bounty of at least $100,000 on the head of Lars Vilks and 50,000 dollars on [[Ulf Johansson (editor)|Ulf Johansson]], editor-in-chief of ''Nerikes Allehanda''. The statement was found in an audio file on an Islamist website and was read by a person who identified himself as [[Abu Omar al-Baghdadi]], the purported head of the Islamic State of Iraq. "We announce a reward of $100,000 to anyone who kills this infidel criminal. This reward will be raised to $150,000 if he is slaughtered like a lamb," the statement said. The statement also threatened attacks on Swedish companies unless unspecified "crusaders" issued an apology. Vilks responded to the statement by saying: "I suppose this makes my art project a bit more serious. It's also good to know how much one is worth".{{cite news |title=Al-Qaida: Bounty on Swedish cartoonist |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070915/ap_on_re_mi_ea/al_qaida_cartoonist_1 |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=2007-09-15 |accessdate=2007-09-15}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite news|title=Al-Qaeda puts bounties on heads of Swedes |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8498/20070915/ |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-09-15 |accessdate=2007-09-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070918190204/http://www.thelocal.se/8498/20070915/ |archivedate=2007-09-18 |df= }}{{cite news |title=Bounty set over Prophet cartoon |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6996553.stm|publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=2007-09-15 |accessdate=2007-09-15}} The United States-based [[SITE Institute]] has reported that websites run by militant Islamists have listed the names of over 100 Swedish companies with addresses, maps and logos. The websites called for their readers to boycott these firms and "take revenge" on Sweden for the publication of the drawings. The [[European Council for Fatwa and Research]] (ECFR) and the [[Federation of Islamic Organizations in Europe]] (FIOE) both condemned the death threats against Vilks and Johansson. ECFR also said it planned to issue a "counter [[fatwa]]" against the threats.{{cite news|title=European Muslims condemn death sentence |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8517/20070917/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-09-17 |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027165042/http://www.thelocal.se/8517/20070917/ |archivedate=2007-10-27 |df= }} The [[World Association of Newspapers]] (WAN), which represents over 18,000 newspapers around the world, issued a statement where it condemned the death threats and expressed support for ''Nerikes Allehanda'' in its right to publish the drawing.{{cite press release |title=WAN Backs Swedish Publishers in Freedom of Expression Dispute |publisher=[[World Association of Newspapers]] |date=2007-09-17 |url=http://www.wan-press.org/article15067.html |accessdate=2007-09-19}} === 9 March 2010 arrests === On 9 March 2010, seven people were arrested in the [[Republic of Ireland]] over an alleged plot to assassinate Vilks. The arrested were originally from Morocco and Yemen and had refugee status.{{cite news |first=Shawn |last=Pogatchnik|title=Irish arrest 7 over threat to kill Swedish artist |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/E/EU_PROPHET_DRAWINGS?SITE=NYBUE&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |publisher=[[The Buffalo News]]/[[Associated Press]] |date=2010-03-09 |accessdate=2010-03-09}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite news |title=Arrests over alleged plot to kill cartoonist |url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0309/waterford.html |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] |date=2010-03-09 |accessdate=2010-03-09}}{{cite news |first=Sarah |last=Stack |title=Seven held in Ireland over plot to assassinate cartoonist Lars Vilks |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/seven-held-in-ireland-over-plot-to-assassinate-cartoonist-lars-vilks-1918672.html |publisher=[[The Independent]] |date=2010-03-09 |accessdate=2010-03-09}} Of the seven, three men and two women were arrested in [[Waterford (city)|Waterford]] and [[Tramore]] and another man and woman at [[Ballincollig]], near [[Cork (city)|Cork]]. [[Garda Síochána]] (the Irish police force), which conducted the arrests with support from the [[counter-terror]] [[Special Detective Unit]] and the National Support Services, said the suspects range in age from mid 20s to late 40s.{{cite press release|title=Searches in Waterford and Cork on the 9/3/10. |publisher=[[Garda Síochána]] |date=2010-03-09 |url=http://www.garda.ie/Controller.aspx?Page=5105 |accessdate=2010-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616194353/http://www.garda.ie/Controller.aspx?Page=5105 |archivedate=2011-06-16 |df= }} They (Garda Síochána) also added that throughout the investigation they had been "working closely with law enforcement agencies in the United States and in a number of European countries". The same day, [[Colleen R. LaRose]] from the [[Philadelphia]], US, suburbs, had her federal indictment unsealed charging her with trying to recruit [[Islamic terrorist]]s to murder Vilks.{{cite news |title=American Colleen LaRose Called Herself Jihad Jane |url=http://abcnews.go.com/WN/TheLaw/colleen-larose-jihad-jane-indicted-charges-helping-terrorists/story?id=10055608|publisher= ''[[ABC News]]'' |date= May 9, 2010| author = Emily Friedman and Jason Ryan }} === 2010 Stockholm bombings === {{Main|2010 Stockholm bombings}} An emailed threat sent to a news agency and to the [[Swedish Security Service]] occurred made reference to this incident.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/sweden/8196754/Suspected-suicide-bomb-in-central-Stockholm-injures-two-and-panics-shoppers.html "Suspected suicide bomb in central Stockholm injures two and panics shoppers"][https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/12/stockholm-sweden-bombs-explosions "Stockholm explosions leave one dead and two injured"] Afterwards, two bombs exploded, injuring two people and killing the would-be attacker.{{cite news |title=Explosions in Stockholm believed to be failed terrorist attack |first=Per |last=Nyberg |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/europe/12/11/sweden.explosion/index.html?hpt=T1 |newspaper=[[CNN]] |date=12 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thelocal.se/30782/20101212/ |title=Stockholm suicide blast a terror attack: police |last=Landes |first=David |newspaper=[[The Local]] |accessdate=12 December 2010 |date=12 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215180203/http://www.thelocal.se/30782/20101212 |archivedate=15 December 2010 |df= }}{{cite news |title=Stockholm blasts kill one and John F. |title=Stockholm Hit by Blasts After E-Mail Warning |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/12/world/europe/12sweden.html?_r=1&hp |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=11 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130621210419/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/12/world/europe/12sweden.html?_r=1&hp| archivedate=June 21, 2013| deadurl= no}} === 2010 Copenhagen terror plot === {{Main|2010 Copenhagen terror plot}} At the time of the December 2010 terror arrests, Lars Vilks' home page was subject to a hacker attack. According to Vilks' blog, the hacker declared the attacks would be continued with no end and that the targets are Vilks, [[Kurt Westergaard]], and [[Geert Wilders]].[http://www.vilks.net/2010/12/30/del-1138-efter-senaste-hacket/ Lars Vilks blog, Del 1138: Efter senaste hacket]{{Primary source-inline|date=February 2015}} === 2013 Al-Qaeda's most wanted === In 2013, cartoonist [[Charb|Stéphane "Charb" Charbonnier]] was added to [[Al-Qaeda]]'s most wanted list, along with Lars Vilks and three ''Jyllands-Posten'' staff members: [[Kurt Westergaard]], [[Carsten Juste]], and [[Flemming Rose]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thewire.com/global/2013/03/al-qaeda-most-wanted-list/62673/|title=Look Who's on Al Qaeda's Most-Wanted List|author=Dashiell Bennet|date=1 Mar 2013|work=The Wire}}{{cite news|url=http://time.com/3657246/paris-charlie-hebdo-shooting/|title=Paris Police Say 12 Dead After Shooting at Charlie Hebdo|author=Conal Urquhart|work=Time}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/11330505/Murdered-Charlie-Hebdo-cartoonist-was-on-al-Qaeda-wanted-list.html|title=Murdered Charlie Hebdo cartoonist was on al Qaeda wanted list|author=Victoria Ward|work=The Telegraph}} === 2015 Copenhagen shootings === {{Main|2015 Copenhagen shootings}} On 14 February 2015, [[2015 Copenhagen shootings#Krudttønden attack|shots were fired]] at a public meeting in Denmark attended by Vilks, leaving one civilian dead and three policemen wounded.https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/14/us-denmark-shooting-idUSKBN0LI0N720150214 The attacker fled after a brief gunfight with police and was later shot dead the next day after committing another shooting at a [[Jewish]] [[synagogue]], killing one person and injuring two policemen. {{cite news|last1=MARTIN|first1=ARTHUR|title='Our purpose is to destroy you. We will come to you with slaughter and death' Read more: http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2956592/He-went-prison-gang-member-came-wanting-wage-holy-war-Friend-says-Copenhagen-gunman-radicalised-serving-sentence-stabbing-teen.html#ixzz3n6yV0rzc|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2956592/He-went-prison-gang-member-came-wanting-wage-holy-war-Friend-says-Copenhagen-gunman-radicalised-serving-sentence-stabbing-teen.html|accessdate=29 September 2015}} == See also == {{Div col}} * [[2017 Basirhat communal violence]] * [[Charlie Hebdo shooting]] * [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy]] * [[Islam in Sweden]] * [[Depictions of Muhammad]] * [[Islam and animals]] * [[Islam and blasphemy]] {{Div col end}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == *[http://www.vilks.net/wp-content/uploads/2007/07/muhammed-rondelllit.JPG Cartoon on Lars Vilks' website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100315195725/http://www.stockholmnews.com/more.aspx?NID=4982 "Lars Vilks Cartoon" Stockholm News; March 13, 2010] {{Depictions of Muhammad|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Caricature]] [[Category:Islam-related controversies in Europe]] [[Category:Events relating to freedom of expression]] [[Category:2007 controversies]] [[Category:Censorship in Islam]] [[Category:Islam in Sweden]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Muhammad]]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} [[Image:DavidIofScotland.jpg|150px|thumb|right|David I, who codified the ''Laws of the Bretts and Scotts''.]]
The '''Leges inter Brettos et Scottos''' or '''Laws of the Brets and Scots''' was a legal [[Codification (law)|codification]] under [[David I of Scotland]] (reigned 1124 – 1153). Only a small fragment of the original document survives, describing the penalties for several offences against people.
Historically, the term "Brets" refers to [[Brythonic languages|Brythonic]] peoples, while "Scots" refers to [[Goidelic languages|Gaelic]]-speaking peoples. [[William Forbes Skene|Skene]] however, asserted that here "Scots" refers to all of the peoples living north of the firths of [[Firth of Clyde|Clyde]] and [[Firth of Forth|Forth]].<ref>{{Harvcolnb|Skene|1890|p=217}} In ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=tDsUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA217 The Tribe in Scotland]''</ref>
Aside from the document's intrinsic importance to [[History of Scotland|Scottish history]], it is significant in its similarity to corresponding areas both of Irish [[Early Irish law|Brehon law]] and of [[Welsh law]], which are better-preserved than the laws of medieval southern Scotland, allowing reasonable conjectures to be made regarding the laws and customs of the region, as few historical records exist.
The '''Laws''' or their precursor were relevant in the early twelfth century, as the ''Laws of the Four Burghs'' (Latin: ''Leges Quatuor Burgorum'') explicitly banned parts of it relating to the ''cro'' (or [[weregild]]).<ref>{{Harvcolnb|Seebohm|1902|p=298}} ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=EROFAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA298 Clause XVII]'' of the ''Leges Quatuor Burgorum''</ref><ref>{{Harvcolnb|Anonymous|1868|p=10}} the text of ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=CUpkgY6ivDoC&pg=RA1-PA10 XVII. De blodewit et consimilibus]'' in the ''Leges Quatuor Burgorum''</ref> <ref group="expl">The ''Laws of the Four Burghs'' is dated between 1135 and 1157, and there is uncertainty and some contention in establishing the specific date. The four burghs were then [[Stirling]], Edinburgh, [[Lanark]], and [[Linlithgow]], with the latter two replaced by [[Roxburgh]] and [[Berwick-upon-Tweed|Berwick]] in 1168.</ref>
The '''Laws''' are known to have been relevant until 1305, as [[Edward I of England]] specifically abolished them in that year,<ref>{{Harvcolnb|Seebohm|1902|p=298}} ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=EROFAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA298 1305 abolishment of the laws by Edward I]''</ref> following his invasion of Scotland. There is no further mention of them, and when Scotland successfully [[Wars of Scottish Independence|reasserted its independence]], the [[feudalism|feudal]] [[Scots law]] then became applicable.
== The surviving clauses ==
The surviving clauses<ref>{{Harvcolnb|Seebohm|1902|pp=307–318}} ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=EROFAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA307 Leges Inter Brettos et Scotos]'' (annotated)</ref> show the society's origins as a [[tribe|tribal]] culture, where a perpetrator's family is responsible for the perpetrator's transgressions, and the family of a victim is compensated for the loss of a family member. As with other [[Celt]]ic societies, the rights and obligations of women are explicitly guaranteed (though at a lesser standing than that of men). Marriages are treated as relationships between different families, and payments accrue to the family of the victim's spouse under some circumstances, but accrue to the victim's family under other circumstances.
'''Definition of the penalties'''
* Penalties for death, including honour-price (clause LV) – ''cro'', ''enach'', and ''galnes'' (cf. Irish ''crólige báis'' relating to ''[[éraic]]'', Irish ''enech'', and Welsh ''[[galanas]]'', resp.). Payment is made to the victims or their families. This is the feature of tribal law commonly known in English as a [[weregild]]. * Penalties for homicides that breach the king's peace (clause LVI) – These are separate from other penalties that might result from killing a person. It includes breaches to the peace of lesser individuals (such as breaching the peace of a noble), which have lesser penalties. Payment is made to the person whose peace was breached. * Penalties for wounding or insults to personal honour (clauses LVII and LVIII) – ''kelchin'' or ''gelchach'' (cf. Irish ''enech'' and Welsh ''sarhad''). Payment is made to the victims or their families. Penalties are distinguished for greater and lesser wounds (e.g., different penalties for drawing blood than for a wound that does not draw blood).
'''Penalty amount according to social position'''
The amounts to be paid were on a scale according to the social position of the victim, with the king at the top with the greatest value, then with a lesser amount for his son or high-ranking noble, an even lesser amount for other nobles, and so on down to the least amount for a common person. Amounts for homicide were given both as a number of cows, and as an equivalent amount of gold. Amounts for wounding or insult were given in gold only.
Payments for a female victim were one third less than that of her husband (but equal to that of her brother if she were unmarried), and make clear that women retained their original kinship and rights after marriage, as death penalties were owed by her family (and not by her husband's family), while death payments were made to her family (and not to the husband's family). Also, the importance of the marriage is acknowledged in that some payments for insult accrue to the spouse of the victim, rather than to the victim's family.

The [[Woodstock|Woodstock Music & Art Fair]] was a [[music festival]] held on a 600-acre (2.4 km²; 240 ha, 0.94 mi²) dairy farm in the rural town of [[Bethel, New York]] from August 15 to August 18, 1969. Thirty-two acts performed during the sometimes rainy weekend in front of nearly half a million concertgoers. It is widely regarded as one of the greatest moments in popular music history and was listed on ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s "50 Moments That Changed the History of Rock and Roll".{{cite web|title=50 Moments That Changed Rock and Roll: Otis and Jimi Burn it Up|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/50-moments-that-changed-rock-and-roll-otis-and-jimi-burn-it-up-20040624|publisher=Rolling Stone}}{{cite web| url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/6085488/woodstock_in_1969| title=Woodstock in 1969| date=2004-06-24| accessdate=2008-04-17| publisher=Rolling Stone}} ==Friday, August 15 to Saturday, August 16== The first day officially began at 5:07 p.m. with Richie Havens and featured folk artists. 32 acts performed during the sometimes rainy weekend in front of nearly half a million concertgoers. === [[Richie Havens]] {{cite web|title=The Woodstock '69 Lineup|website=Woodstock.com|url=http://www.woodstock.com/lineup/|accessdate=19 November 2017}} === 5:07pm – 6:00pm # "From the Prison # "[[Get Together (Chet Powers song)|Get Together]]" # "From the Prison" (reprise) # "The Minstrel from Gault" # "I'm a Stranger Here" # "[[High Flying Bird (song)|High Flying Bird]]" # "I Can't Make It Anymore" # "[[With a Little Help from My Friends]]" # "[[Handsome Johnny]]" # "[[Strawberry Fields Forever]] / [[Hey Jude]]" # "Freedom ([[Sometimes I Feel Like a Motherless Child|Motherless Child]])" === [[Swami Satchidananda]] === 7:10pm – 7:20pm *Gave the invocation for the festival === [[Sweetwater (band)|Sweetwater]] === 7:30pm – 8:10pm{{refn|group=nb|.While some sources list "Day Song" as being played, as of now, there is only a very short excerpt recording of it that might be from Woodstock. As per Nancy Nevins, Sweetwater did not end the set with "Day Song".}} # "Motherless Child" # "Look Out" # "For Pete's Sake" # "What's Wrong" # "Crystal Spider" # "Two Worlds" # "Why Oh Why" # "Let the Sunshine In" # "Oh Happy Day" === [[Bert Sommer]] === 8:20pm – 9:15pm # "Jennifer" # "The Road to Travel" # "I Wondered Where You Be" # "She's Gone" # "Things Are Going My Way" # "And When It's Over" # "Jeanette" # "[[America (Paul Simon song)|America]]" # "A Note That Read" # "Smile" === [[Tim Hardin]] === 9:20pm – 9:45pm # "[[How Can We Hang On to a Dream?]]" # "Susan" # "[[If I Were a Carpenter (song)|If I Were a Carpenter]]" # "Reason to Believe" # "You Upset the Grace of Living When You Lie" # "Speak Like a Child" # "Snow White Lady" # "Blues on My Ceiling" # "Simple Song of Freedom" # "Misty Roses" === [[Ravi Shankar]] === with a three-song set, played through the rain

His set was preceded by at least two instrumentals by [[The Grease Band]]. === [[Joe Cocker]] === 2:00pm – 3:25pm # "Dear Landlord" # "Something Comin' On" # "Do I Still Figure in Your Life" # "[[Feelin' Alright?|Feelin' Alright]]" # "[[Just Like a Woman]]" # "[[Let's Go Get Stoned (R&B song)|Let's Go Get Stoned]]" # "I Don't Need a Doctor" # "[[I Shall Be Released]]" # "Hitchcock Railway" # "Something to Say" # "[[With a Little Help from My Friends]]" * After Joe Cocker's set, a thunderstorm disrupted the events for several hours. === [[Country Joe and the Fish]] === 6:30pm – 8:00pm # "Rock & Soul Music" # "(Thing Called) Love" # "Not So Sweet Martha Lorraine" # "Sing, Sing, Sing" # "Summer Dresses" # "Friend, Lover, Woman, Wife" # "Silver and Gold" # "Maria" # "Love Machine" # "Ever Since You Told Me That You Love Me (I'm a Nut)" # "Short Jam (instrumental)" # "Crystal Blues" # "Rock & Soul Music (Reprise)" # "[[The "Fish" Cheer/I-Feel-Like-I'm-Fixin'-to-Die Rag]]" === [[Ten Years After]] === 8:15pm – 9:15pm # "[[Spoonful]]" # "[[Good Morning Little Schoolgirl]]" # "Hobbit" # "I Can't Keep from Crying Sometimes" # "Help Me" # "I'm Going Home" === [[The Band]] === 10:00pm – 10:50pm # "[[Chest Fever]]" # "Don't Do It" # "Tears of Rage" # "We Can Talk" # "[[Long Black Veil]]" # "Don't You Tell Henry" # "[[Ain't No More Cane]]" # "[[This Wheel's on Fire]]" # "[[I Shall Be Released]]" # "[[The Weight]]" # "[[Loving You Is Sweeter Than Ever]]" === [[Johnny Winter]] === 12:00am – 1:05am featuring his brother, [[Edgar Winter]], on three songs. # "Mama, Talk to Your Daughter" # "Leland Mississippi Blues" # "Mean Town Blues" # "You Done Lost Your Good Thing Now" / "Mean Mistreater" # "I Can't Stand It" (with [[Edgar Winter]]) # "[[Tobacco Road (song)|Tobacco Road]]" (with Edgar Winter) # "Tell the Truth" (with Edgar Winter) # "[[Johnny B.
