The holy table continued to be located at the eastern end of the building.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=25–28}} Bishop Broughton supported the Tractarian views of Allwood, but his successor, [[Frederic Barker]], who became bishop in 1855, was strongly Evangelical.{{cite web|last=Cable|first=K.J.|title=Barker, Frederic (1808–1882)|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/barker-frederic-2934/text4247|work=Australian Dictionary of Biography|publisher=National Centre of Biography, Australian National University|volume=3|accessdate=21 December 2013|year=1969}} The division in style between St James' and the "low church" ethos that predominated in the Sydney Diocese began at this time.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=25–28}} ===Changes: 1884–1904=== During the 1880s Sydney became a prosperous city, commerce and industry flourished, and the suburbs expanded. As more churches were built and fewer people lived in the heart of the city, the congregation of St James' Church shrank. The challenge that it faced was to minister effectively to city workers, rather than dwellers, to serve the poor of the city, and to attract those whose preference was for the style of worship and intellectual, topical preaching that distinguished St James' from many of the newly created parish churches.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=26–34}} The young Henry Latimer Jackson, from Cambridge, was appointed in 1885. He introduced weekday services and a magazine called ''The Kalendar'', one of Australia's first parish papers.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|page=9}} He also lectured at Sydney University, addressed conferences, spoke at synod and acted as secretary to the newly established [[Sydney Church of England Grammar School|Sydney Church of England Boys' Grammar School]].{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=10}} However, his sermons were described as "not so much opposed, as simply not understood".{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=11}} He resigned in 1895 after accepting a position in the [[Diocese of Ely]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article133225885 |title=Religious |newspaper=[[The Newcastle Herald|Newcastle Morning Herald & Miners' Advocate]]|date=15 June 1895 |accessdate=20 December 2013 |page=11}} [[File:1 St James j.JPG|thumb|left|upright=1.25|alt=The interior looking towards an arched exit. There are rows of pews and a wide centre aisle. The ceiling is coffered into decorative square shapes. There is a large gallery of dark wood with a curving balustrade across the back of the church.|The gallery at the western end of the church is the only one to remain]] Although Sydney was prospering, St James' had an acute shortage of money and "the government considered resuming the site for a city railway".{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=11}}{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=26}} The trustees at this time leased the [[Clergy house|parsonage]] and, in 1894, used the money for urgent restoration to the exterior of the building. The architect [[Varney Parkes]] replaced the old [[spire]], using copper that was pre-weathered so that there was no radical change in its appearance.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=28}} He removed infilling from the north portico and designed a new portico and entrance to the tower to match that of the eastern vestry. The result was to make the north face of the building its most significant aspect.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=26}} Jackson's successor was [[William Carr Smith]], a man with socialist ideals and a commitment to social reform and spiritual outreach.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=34–41}} He preached long and engaging sermons inside the church and for a time in the open air in [[The Domain]] as well.{{sfn|St. James' Church (Sydney, NSW)|1919|p=25}} Carr Smith had brought with him from England the "most recent developments" in the restoration of ancient liturgy, so he was able to help St James' play a "notable part" in Sydney's revival of Anglo-Catholicism, setting "new standards of ceremonial".{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=12}} To serve these purposes the architect [[John H. Buckeridge]] was employed to transform the building's interior, completing the work in 1901.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=34–41}} The most significant change was the new emphasis given to the [[altar]], which was made the focus of attention and "flanked by the pulpit, reading desks and lectern."{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=21}} The "principal features" under the Carr Smith plan were the construction of the [[apse]], set into the eastern vestry to create a [[Sanctuary#Sanctuary as an altar|sanctuary]]; the raising of the [[chancel]] floor which created a platform, five steps above the nave for the [[Choir (architecture)|choir]], framed by the organ divided into two sections; the making of a new, unobtrusive entrance to the tower and western gallery; and the removal of the box pews and the eastern and northern galleries.{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=21–22}} The memorial plaques were also rearranged. The choir was ornamented with a [[mosaic]] floor and ornate brasswork which complemented the large brass eagle lectern by the English ecclesiastical suppliers, J. Wippell and Company, that commemorated Canon Robert Allwood.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=26–34}}{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=34–41}} The floor of the pulpit was made from parts of the old three-decker one.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15850397 |title=The Churches – Centenary of St. James' |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=4 October 1919 |accessdate=11 October 2013 |page=7 }} The organ, refurbished and enlarged by Davidson of Sydney, was installed in 1903.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=34–41}} With the removal of the organ, the south vestry was made into a side chapel. Eight large [[stained glass]] windows were installed between 1903 and 1913, along with a new pulpit, altar and [[retable]], all of which were given as memorials.{{sfn|Australian Heritage Commission|1981|pp=2; 96}} Another improvement was "the placing of double windows on the King-street side to shut out the sound of the traffic, which hitherto has been a serious annoyance to both the officiating clergymen and the congregation".{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14367351 |title=St. James' Church |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=12 February 1901 |accessdate=8 October 2011 |page=6 }} In 1897, St James' Hall was offered to Father Dorotheos Bakalliarios, a [[Greek Orthodox Church|Greek Orthodox]] priest from [[Samos]] for Orthodox services in Sydney.{{sfn|Jupp|2001|p=409}} In 1904 the diocesan architect, [[Burcham Clamp|John Burcham Clamp]], was employed to design a new [[Church hall|parish hall]].{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=34–41}} ===20th century=== [[File:Queen's Square, Sydney c1930.jpg|thumb|upright=1.75|alt=Aerial black and white photo of the junction of Macquarie and King Streets when traffic could still run from one into the other. Buses and other vehicles are on the roads and the now demolished building at the corner can be seen|[[Queen's Square, Sydney]] c1930]] In 1900, the Governor, [[William Lygon, 7th Earl Beauchamp|Earl Beauchamp]], presented to the church a number of embroidered [[Stole (vestment)|stoles]] made by the [[Warham Guild]] of London, along with [[cope]]s and [[chasuble]]s.{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=31}} The centenary of the laying of the foundation stone was celebrated in October 1919 with a program of events that extended over nine days. Festivities included services at which the Bishops of [[Armidale, New South Wales|Armidale]] and [[Bathurst, New South Wales|Bathurst]] were special preachers, music, processions, a [[Magic lantern|lantern]] lecture on "Old Sydney" by the municipal librarian, and social events such as a ferry outing and a luncheon at which the chief guest was the Governor [[Walter Edward Davidson|Sir Walter Davidson]] accompanied by his wife [[Margaret Davidson|Lady Davidson]]. Also scheduled was a welcome to soldiers returned from the [[World War I|Great War]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article123218764 |title=Hundredth Anniversary of Famous Sydney Church|newspaper=[[The Sunday Times (Sydney, Australia)|The Sunday Times]]|date=5 October 1919 |accessdate=9 October 2013 |page=23 |publisher=}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15850290 |title=Advertising – St James Church, King Street (1819–1919) – Programme of the centenary festival|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=4 October 1919 |accessdate=18 September 2013 |page=5 }} An illustrated historical memoir was produced and sold for two [[Shilling (Australian)|shillings]].{{sfn|St. James' Church (Sydney, NSW)|1919}} The celebrations for the centenary of the Oxford Movement occurred during the tenure of the eighth rector of St James', [[Philip Arthur Micklem|Philip Micklem]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16992677 |title=Oxford Movement |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=NSW |date=20 July 1933 |accessdate=3 November 2013 |page=8 }} However, "they were not centred on the cathedral, but on St James'", Sydney being the only Australian diocese that "failed officially to observe the occasion".{{sfn|Frappell|1997|p=133}} Micklem chaired a rally on 19 July 1933 in St James' Hall that was attended by governor [[Philip Game]] and Lady Game, "and five bishops representing three states."{{sfn|Frappell|1997|p=131}} The 180th anniversary of the Oxford Movement fell in the 21st century, and the rector of St James' preached at the commemoration.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140121043122/http://sjks.org.au/wp-content/uploads/WN-7-July-2013.pub-DW.pdf| url=http://sjks.org.au/wp-content/uploads/WN-7-July-2013.pub-DW.pdf|title=Weekly pewsheet|date=7 July 2013|archivedate= 21 January 2014|publisher=St James' King Street|accessdate=21 January 2014}} Micklem was "a pioneer advocate of the preservation of early colonial architecture".{{cite book|first=K. J. |last=Cable|chapter=Micklem, Philip Arthur (1876–1965)|title= [[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]|publisher= National Centre of Biography, Australian National University|chapter-url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/micklem-philip-arthur-7570/text13213|accessdate= 14 September 2013|year=1986|volume=10}} As the century progressed, there were a number of threats to the church's historic environment, which includes Greenway's Law Courts and [[Hyde Park Barracks, Sydney|Hyde Park Barracks]].{{sfn|Fitzgerald|1999|p=39}}{{cite web | url = http://www.dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/wyatt_annie | title = Wyatt, Annie | accessdate = 17 January 2014 | author = Julie Blyth | year = 2008 | work = Dictionary of Sydney | publisher = Dictionary of Sydney Trust}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13992199 |title=The Sydney Law Courts |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=NSW |date=6 August 1895 |accessdate=14 January 2014 |page=5 }} In spite of the threats to these colonial era buildings, they survived to form an important Sydney precinct.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=27}} Both the building and the organisation continued to serve the city. During [[World War II]], for example, the crypt was used as a "Hostel for Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen"{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=20}} and the ninth rector, Edwin John Davidson, incumbent during that period, "gained fame" for the church with his "pungent sermons on current affairs".{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=13}} The eleventh rector, Frank Cuttriss, had an [[Ecumenism|ecumenical]] outlook – he was a member of a meeting of the [[World Council of Churches]] at [[Uppsala]] and an observer to the [[Second Vatican Council]].{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=49}} St James' was the locus of many notable events throughout the 20th century, including weddings and funerals of famous, significant or notorious people, visits from theologians and senior clerics, and when needed, services for the [[Lutheranism|Lutheran]] communities.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18184956 |title=King Gustav |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=7 November 1950 |accessdate=20 December 2013 |page=9}} At the wedding of singer [[Gladys Moncrieff]] and Tom Moore on 20 May 1924, the crowd in the streets nearby was so large that traffic was brought to a standstill, several women fell and two were so badly hurt they were taken to hospital.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article67141404 |title=Gladys Moncrieff's Wedding |newspaper=[[The Advocate (Tasmania)|The Advocate]] |date=21 May 1924 |accessdate=8 April 2012 |page=5 |publisher=}} At the time Moncrieff was appearing in ''[[The Merry Widow]]'' and returned to the stage on the night of her wedding.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article51765526 |title=Peer and skating star wed |newspaper=[[The Australian Women's Weekly]] |location=Sydney|date=18 November 1939 |accessdate=8 April 2012 |page=13 }}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16134064 |title=Theatrical Wedding |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=21 May 1924 |accessdate=8 April 2012 |page=14}} St James' was represented in the opening ceremonies of the [[Sydney Harbour Bridge]] by a [[Float (parade)|float]] in the form of the church building.{{cite web |url= http://nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn6246928 |title=St James Church float at the opening ceremony of the Sydney Harbour Bridge|date=March 1932 |work=Digital Collections – Pictures – National Library of Australia |accessdate=17 November 2013}} The church was "packed to the doors" when the seventh rector, [[Francis Wentworth-Sheilds|W.F. Wentworth-Sheilds]], officiated at the "impressive funeral" of [[Walter Liberty Vernon]] in 1914.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15478548 |title=Late Colonel Vernon |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=NSW |date=20 January 1914 |accessdate=27 March 2014 |page=7 }} In 1950, four thousand people were reported to have lined the streets after the State funeral at St. James' of the first [[Australia–Sweden relations|Minister for Sweden in Australia]], Constans Lundquist, who died suddenly at the Swedish Legation in Sydney.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27575273 |title=Envoy Dies Suddenly |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=28 April 1950 |accessdate=11 October 2013 |page=1}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18159632 |title=Funeral of Diplomat |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=1 May 1950 |accessdate=11 October 2013 |page=3}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27571887 |title=Funeral of Diplomat |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=2 May 1950 |accessdate=11 October 2013 |page=5}}The ''Order of the state funeral service of his late Excellency Mr. O. C. G. Lundquist, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of Sweden, Monday, 1st May, 1950 at 3 p.m'' is in the collections of the [[National Library of Australia]] (call number [http://nla.gov.au/nla.cat-vn1476153 JAFp BIO 286]) Controversial former Governor-General, [[John Kerr (governor-general)|Sir John Kerr]] had a private funeral and memorial service in St James' in 1991 rather than a State funeral because of his fall from favour as the result of his decision to sack the [[Whitlam government]] in 1975.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article122351646 |title=Sir John Kerr dies alone at 76: the storm goes on|newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]]|date=26 March 1991 |accessdate=24 September 2013 |page=1}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article122351771 |title=Class traitor or saviour? Votes still out|newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]]|date=26 March 1991 |accessdate=24 September 2013 |page=8}} Delivering the sermon at St James' during an ecumenical event on 14 October 1993, Archbishop [[Desmond Tutu]] thanked Australians for supporting the struggle against [[Apartheid in South Africa|apartheid]].{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.cat-vn128996|last=Osmond|first=Warren|title=Six years on, Tutu says thanks|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|location=Sydney, NSW|date=16 October 1993|page=22}} During the 20th century both choral and organ musical components developed to a high standard and were integral to the liturgy at St James'.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14095369 |title=St James' Church |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=26 July 1897 |accessdate=8 October 2011 |page=9}} In addition, music was offered to the wider community in the form of recitals, often in ways that elucidate the liturgy and take advantage of church acoustics and sacred settings. Weekday recitals, such as the organ recitals given in 1936 of music by [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]],{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17337833 |title=St James's Church Organ |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=25 March 1936 |accessdate=12 October 2013 |page=7}} continued in addition to the music played on Sundays. ===21st century=== [[File:SydneyStJames gobeirne.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.25|alt=A recent photo. The church is seen framed by the gateposts of the nearby Barracks. Its steeple is seen against a backdrop of multi-storey buildings.|St James' Church in 2006]] In the 21st century, St James' continues its work in the city centre via its ministry and engagement in the issues of the day. In the 19th century, there were controversies about tractarianism; in the 20th, there was the impact of the two world wars; in the 21st century, the church has confronted the difficult and topical issues of violence, euthanasia,{{cite web|title=The Ethics of Voluntary Assisted Dying|url=http://www.dwdnsw.org.au/ves/index.php/article/videos|work=The Videos from the Parliamentary Forum – 4 Nov 2013 Part 4: The Reverend Andrew Sempell – Rector St James Anglican Church Sydney (video)|publisher=Dying with Dignity NSW|accessdate=21 January 2014|date=14 November 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140118232706/http://www.dwdnsw.org.au/ves/index.php/article/videos|archivedate=18 January 2014|df=dmy-all}} refugees,In February 2014, an information session about refugees and asylum seekers in Australia was chaired by the rector. Former [[List of Australian Commonwealth Ombudsmen|Commonwealth Ombudsman]] [[Allan Asher]] was a participant. {{cite journal|last=Dillon|first=Sarah|title=Understanding our Neighbours|journal=St James' Parish Connections|date=February–March 2014|pages=1–2, 11|publisher=St James' Church, Sydney}}{{cite web|last=Horsburgh|first=Michael|title=On Watching Satan Fall|url=http://sjks.org.au/wp-content/uploads/Horsburgh-Seventh-Sunday-after-Pentecost-7-July-20131.pdf|work=Sermon preached at St James' Church on 7 July 2013|publisher=St James' Church, Sydney|accessdate=21 December 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131223035622/http://sjks.org.au/wp-content/uploads/Horsburgh-Seventh-Sunday-after-Pentecost-7-July-20131.pdf |archivedate=23 December 2013 }} marriage and sexuality.{{cite web|last=Jopson|first=Debra|title=Archbishop challenged over same-sex marriage message|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/archbishop-challenged-over-samesex-marriage-message-20120701-21b32.html|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|location=Sydney, NSW|accessdate=4 November 2013|date=2 July 2012}} The church's relationship with government and the legal community began when the colony was under military government and the Church of England was the [[State religion|established church]]. Due to the church's history and its proximity to the convict barracks (later an immigration centre), the law courts (both the old and the new ones) as well as the New South Wales parliament, the relationship continues. It is evident in special services attended by the governor as well as the annual service to mark the opening of the [[legal year|law term]].{{cite web|title=2013 Opening of Law Term – Anglican Church Service|url=http://www.lawsociety.com.au/ForSolictors/Events/CLEeventscalendar/Detail/index.htm?eventID=1942&userInputMonth=0&userInputYear=2013|publisher=Law Society of New South Wales|accessdate=14 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140115063511/http://www.lawsociety.com.au/ForSolictors/Events/CLEeventscalendar/Detail/index.htm?eventID=1942&userInputMonth=0&userInputYear=2013|archivedate=15 January 2014|df=dmy-all}} St James' commitment to [[social justice]] and education began in the 19th century with efforts to serve both convicts and settlers. It continued in the 20th with support for people affected by war, for example, when the church became "a busy centre of war-time life".{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=16}} Since early in the 20th century, service to the community has included visits to those imprisoned or ill as well as practical help to the city's homeless{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14200431 |title=St. James' Church |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=15 February 1899 |accessdate=8 October 2011 |page=8}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14434365 |title=St James' Church |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=26 December 1901 |accessdate=8 October 2011 |page=5}}{{cite web|url=http://sjks.org.au/outreach/sister-freda-mission/|title=Sister Freda Mission|year=2014|publisher=St James' King Street|accessdate=18 January 2014}} and an annual schedule of educational seminars at the St James' Institute.{{cite web|title=2013 Programme|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140125080720/http://sjks.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/SJI-handbook-2013.pdf|url=http://sjks.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/SJI-handbook-2013.pdf|publisher=St James' Institute|accessdate=25 January 2014|year=2013|archivedate=25 January 2014}} On 6 February 2012, the rector Andrew Sempell officiated at a thanksgiving for [[Queen Elizabeth II]] to mark the [[Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II|sixtieth anniversary]] of her accession to the throne in a service attended by the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Sydney, Cardinal [[George Pell]] and the [[Governor of New South Wales]], [[Marie Bashir]] and on 9 September 2015, when Queen Elizabeth II became the longest-serving British monarch and Queen of Australia, there was a special [[Evening Prayer (Anglican)|Choral Evensong]] service to give thanks.{{cite web|last=Flowers|first=John|title=Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee|url=http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/hansart.nsf/V3Key/LA20120215033|work=Hansard: Legislative Assembly|publisher=Parliament of New South Wales|accessdate=19 December 2013|location=Sydney|page=8328|date=15 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219034523/http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/hansart.nsf/V3Key/LA20120215033|archivedate=19 December 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite journal|last1=Sempell|first1=Andrew|title=Long to Reign Over Us|journal=Parish Connections|issue=October/November 2015|page=7|url=http://sjks.org.au/wp-content/uploads/Parish-Connections-October-November-2015.pdf|accessdate=9 October 2015}} At the Jubilee service, the [[Chief Justice of New South Wales]], [[Tom Bathurst]], read the first lesson and the service concluded with the [[Advance Australia Fair|Australian National Anthem]] and an organ postlude of [[Edward Elgar]]'s ''[[Pomp and Circumstance Marches|Pomp and Circumstance March]] No. 4''. On 23 March 2012, a memorial service for [[Margaret Whitlam]], wife of former [[Prime Minister of Australia]], [[Gough Whitlam]], was attended by Prime Minister [[Julia Gillard]], and several former prime ministers.{{cite news |last=Marr |first=David |authorlink=David Marr (journalist) |title=Life of the party, but she was a woman of simple pleasures |url=http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/political-news/life-of-the-party-but-she-was-a-woman-of-simple-pleasures-20120323-1vpbv.html |accessdate=24 March 2012 |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|location=Sydney, NSW|date=24 March 2012}} {{clear}} ==Description== [[File:St James' Church, Sydney - classical portico on north side.JPG|thumb|upright=1.25|alt=Columns supporting an entablature and pediment extending from the church to create a covered entrance|North [[portico]]]] ===Architecture=== One of Greenway's finest works, St James' is listed on the Register of the National estate.{{sfn|Apperly|Lind|1971|p=25}}{{sfn|Australian Heritage Commission|1981|pp=2; 95}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/heritageapp/ViewHeritageItemDetails.aspx?ID=2423799|title=St James Church Including Interior, Courtyards, Perimeter Walls and Fences|last=|first=|date=|website=Office of Environment & Heritage|publisher=NSW Government|access-date=}} It has been called an "architectural gem"{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=23}} and was featured by [[Dan Cruickshank]] in the [[BBC]] television series ''[[Around the World in 80 Treasures]].''2005, Episode 3. From 1966 to 1993 the spire of St James' appeared on the Australian [[Australian ten-dollar note]] among other Greenway buildings.{{cite web|title=Other Banknotes: paper series|url=http://banknotes.rba.gov.au/otherbanknotes.html|publisher=Reserve Bank of Australia|year=2013|accessdate=23 December 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140127101134/http://banknotes.rba.gov.au/otherbanknotes.html|archivedate=27 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}{{sfn|Cable|Clarke|1982|p=31}} In 1973, the church appeared on a 50 cent [[postage stamp]], one of four in a series illustrating [[Architecture of Australia|Australian architecture]] issued to commemorate the opening of the [[Sydney Opera House]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article110745480 |title=New stamp series |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]]|date=31 August 1973 |accessdate=13 January 2014 |page=9}} The Old Supreme Court Building next to the church is of the same date.{{sfn|Freeland|1968|pp=37–38|ps=: In comparison with the heights to which Greenway "soared" with his designs for St James', St Matthew's, Windsor and the Hyde Park Barracks, the Old Supreme Court "was formless, pedestrian and dully anonymous".}} Across the square is Greenway's "masterpiece" [[Hyde Park Barracks, Sydney|Hyde Park Barracks]], designed to align with the church.{{sfn|Freeland|1968|p=40}} Beside the barracks stands Sydney's oldest public building, part of the General Hospital built in 1811 and now known as the [[Sydney Mint|Mint Building]]. Separated from the Mint by the present-day [[Sydney Hospital]] is [[Parliament House, Sydney]], of which the central section is a further part of the early hospital, and is now home to the [[New South Wales State Parliament]].{{sfn|Leary|Leary|1972|pages=34–40}} The church was constructed between 1820 and 1824 with later additions made in 1834 by John Verge who designed the [[vestry|vestries]] at the eastern end.{{sfn|Freeland|1968|p=39}} Apart from these vestries, which retain the established style and proportions, the church externally remains "fine Georgian"{{sfn|Judd|Cable|2000|p=12}} much as Greenway conceived it.{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=21}}{{sfn|Apperly|Irving|Reynolds|1989|p=28}} Relying on the "virtues of simplicity and proportion to achieve his end",{{sfn|Freeland|1968|p=38}} Greenway maintained the [[Neoclassical architecture|classical]] tradition, unaffected by the [[Revivalism (architecture)|Revivalist]] styles that were being promoted in London at the time he arrived in the colony.{{sfn|Freeland|1968|p=37}} He planned the church to align with his earlier Hyde Park Barracks, constructed in 1817–19. The two buildings have similar proportions, [[pilaster]]s and [[gable]]s and together constitute an important example of [[town-planning]].{{sfn|Australian Heritage Commission|1981|pp=2; 95}} Before the advent of high-rise buildings, the 150 foot spire used to "serve as a guide for mariners coming up Port Jackson". St James' originally took the form of a simple rectangular block, without transepts or [[chancel]], with a tower at the western end and a classical portico of the [[Doric order]] on either side. To this has been added Verge's vestry framed by two small [[portico]]s, and a similar portico as an entrance to the tower. The church is built of local brick, its walls divided by brick pilasters into a series of bays. The walls are pierced by large windows with round arched heads in a colour that separates and defines them against the walls. The roof carries over the end walls with the gable forming triangular [[pediment]]s of classical proportions carrying a [[cornice]] across the eaves line. Thus the architectural treatment on the side walls is continued around the end walls.{{sfn|Freeland|1968|p=39}} [[File:1 St James b.JPG|left|thumb|upright=1.25|alt=A symmetrical photo looking down the nave towards the apse and chancel showing the corners of the underside of the western gallery at its edges and the pews with some people sitting in them|The interior looking towards the [[chancel]]]] ===Interior=== The original interior differed greatly in layout from that of the present. There was no structural chancel, the focus of the church being a large pulpit. During the mid 19th century galleries overlooked the pulpit from three sides.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=26}} Of the original galleries, only the western one of [[Australian Red Cedar]] remains in place. The [[coffer]]ed ceiling (an addition from 1882 replacing the original [[lath]] and [[plaster]] ceiling), the low-backed pews (from shortly after) and the predominantly classical memorials all contribute to the present interior retaining the character of a Georgian church. At the eastern end, the communion table is set into a small apse with its semi-dome adorned with gold mosaic tiles that were added in 1960.{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=22}} The altar is a commemorative gift from the Lloyd family, whose son was the first server appointed at St James'.{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=22}} It generally has an [[altar frontal]] in the colour of the [[Liturgical year|liturgical season or festival]]. With no structural choir area, the chancel is built out and into the body of the church as a platform enclosed within gated [[wrought iron]] and brass railings and approached by steps. The mosaic floor of the chancel is ornately with designs showing the [[seven gifts of the Holy Spirit]] (Wisdom, Understanding, Counsel, Ghostly Strength, Knowledge, Godliness and Holy Fear) along with symbols of St James the Great (the staff, scrip, palm, [[scallop#Shell of Saint James|scallop shell]] and hat of the [[pilgrim]]).{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=22}} The chancel is framed on either side by the organ pipes.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=24–25}} There are five large stained glass windows on the northern and southern walls and additional windows in the stairwell to the belltower and on the western wall. Most of them are designed by [[Percy Bacon Brothers]] and the majority were donated as memorials by parishioners in the period from 1900 to 1910. The stained glass fanlight depicting [[James, son of Zebedee|James]] and [[John the Apostle|John]], the sons of [[Zebedee]], was designed by Australian artist Norman Carter in 1930.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=41}}{{cite web|last=Lindsay|first=Frances|title=Carter, Norman St Clair (1875–1963)|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/carter-norman-st-clair-5525|work=Australian Dictionary of Biography|publisher=National Centre of Biography, Australian National University|accessdate=20 December 2013|volume=7|year=1979}} The window behind the [[baptismal font]], depicting Christ with the Children, was repaired and rededicated in 2004 by the fifteenth rector in the presence of the then Primate, [[Peter Carnley]].{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=27}} ===Chapel of the Holy Spirit=== [[File:1 St James m.JPG|thumb|upright=1.25|alt=Image of the panels that make up the artist's abstract interpretation of his subject. Swirls of cool colours in the upper section and swirls of warm colours in the lower with a central circular focus in the middle|Stained glass in the Chapel of the Holy Spirit]] Previously enclosed and used as a vestry and then an organ chamber, the south porch became a chapel in 1903. In 1988, the side chapel was remodelled and dedicated as the Chapel of the Holy Spirit.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=38}} The parish and the [[Australian Bicentenary|Bicentennial Council of New South Wales]] funded the redesign which saw the removal of the infilling from between the columns of the portico and its replacement with stained glass. The award-winning "Creation Window", designed by Australian artist David Wright,{{cite web |url= http://davidwrightstudio.com/ |title=David Wright – Glass Artist |work=davidwrightstudio.com |year=2012 |accessdate=15 November 2013}}{{cite web | url = http://www.dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/stained_glass | title = Stained glass | accessdate = 17 January 2014 | author = Beverley Sherry | year = 2011 | work = Dictionary of Sydney | publisher = Dictionary of Sydney Trust}} spreads across the three walls and represents the interaction of earth, air, fire and water, symbolic of the action of the Spirit in creation, in life and in rebirth in Christ.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=40–41}} The new furniture for the chapel was designed by Leon Sadubin.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article122371838 |title=Magazome: Arts Finely crafted furniture uses local timbers |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]]|date=20 July 1991 |accessdate=19 December 2013 |page=42}} ===Crypt and Children's Chapel=== {{main article|Children's Chapel, St James' Church, Sydney}} Beneath the church is a large [[undercroft]], built of brick and [[groin vault]]ed. It has been used for many purposes: as a residence by Revd Hill's widow and later by a verger; by Canon Allwood as a part-time bedroom; for the parish's schools; and as a shelter by Australian, American and British armed forces during the two world wars.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64033707 |title=A Historic Church |newspaper=[[Illustrated Sydney News]]|date=24 June 1893 |accessdate=6 December 2013 |page=9}} Rector Francis Wentworth-Sheilds gave the city parish "a big role as a drop-in centre for servicemen" during the First World War.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=12}} During the Second World War bed and bedding were provided to over 30,000 Allied servicemen.{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=18}} The western bay on the south side of the crypt is the Chapel of St Mary and the Angels, better known simply as the "[[Children's Chapel, St James' Church, Sydney|Children's Chapel]]". It was opened in 1929 as a chapel for younger children. A specially adapted form of [[Eucharist]] is celebrated there on the first Sunday of the month. All four walls of the chapel and its ceiling are decorated with [[mural]]s designed by the writer and artist [[Ethel Anderson]] and executed by the Turramurra Wall Painters Union, a group of [[Modernism|Modernist]] painters she founded in 1927.{{cite web|url=http://sjks.org.au/childrens-chapel/|title=The Children's Chapel (of St Mary and the Angels)|year=2014|publisher=St James' King Street|accessdate=18 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214052911/http://sjks.org.au/childrens-chapel/|archivedate=14 February 2014|df=dmy-all}} The murals underwent extensive conservation in 1992–1993.{{cite web |title=25 iconic projects |url=http://www.icssydney.com.au/index.php?id=435 |publisher=International Conservation Services |accessdate=28 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63AryAA2A?url=http://www.icssydney.com.au/index.php?id=435 |archivedate=13 November 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }} The crypt was restored by Geoffrey Danks in 1977–78.{{sfn|Cable|Clarke|1982|p=50}} In the 21st century, the bays on either side of the crypt's central corridor are used for a variety of purposes. At the eastern end they house a commercial kitchen. Some bays are used as offices; one (The Chapel of All Souls) contains a [[columbarium]]; another houses a [[lending library]] for parishioners.{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=31}} {{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | header_align = center | header = | image1 = Stained glass window in St James Sydney adjusted.JPG | width1 = 140 | alt1 = St James is shown in layered robes holding a staff across his body and a Bible in his left hand. On his right shoulder is the scallop shell. | caption1 = ''St James'', a memorial to Elsey Fairfax-Ross (1905) | image2 = St James' Church, Sydney 10 Sistine Madonna window crop.JPG | width2 = 144 | alt2 = Mary is shown standing holding the baby Jesus high in her arms | caption2 = Detail of the Sistine Madonna window, based on [[Raphael]]'s paintingGift of Mr & Mrs L.T. Lloyd (''The Church'' 1963, p. 24.) }} ===Memorials, monuments, records=== St James' provides a record of important elements of Sydney's history in both physical and documentary form.{{cite web|title=Church Registers: St James Church of England, Sydney, NSW|url=http://www.bda-online.org.au/files/CR17_ChurchRegister.pdf|publisher=Biographical Database of Australia|date=November 2012|accessdate=3 January 2014}} There are over 300 memorials commemorating important members of 19th century colonial society, people who served the colony generally and parishioners from the 20th century. In addition, many of the stained glass windows and items of furniture have been donated as memorials. For example, the large stained glass window of [[Saint George]] on the northern wall is a memorial to Keith Kinnaird Mackellar, who died in the [[Second Boer War]] aged 20.The inscription reads: "To the Glory of God and in loving memory of Keith Kinnaird Mackellar Lieutenant 7th (Princess Royal) Dragoon Guards who was killed in action at [[Onderstepoort]] South Africa on the 11th July 1900 in the twentieth year of his age. 'Who shall ascend into the hill of the Lord: or who shall rise up in his holy place? He that hath clean hands and pure heart.'" He was the brother of poet [[Dorothea Mackellar]]. These memorials are the reason the church was sometimes called "The [[Westminster Abbey]] of the South".{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=22}} As early as 1876, the wall tablets were described as "full of sad memories to the old inhabitants, interesting reminiscences to those who have studied Australian history".{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70602560 |title=St. James's Church, Sydney|newspaper=[[Australian Town and Country Journal]]|date=8 July 1876 |accessdate=8 October 2011 |page=20 |publisher=}} It contains a detailed list of the memorials The first monument erected in the church was the memorial to Commodore Sir [[James Brisbane]], who died in Sydney on his way to serve in South America in command of [[HMS Warspite (1807)|HMS Warspite]]. It was sculpted by [[Francis Leggatt Chantrey|Sir Francis Chantrey]], sent to Sydney by Lady Brisbane and installed in the church in 1830. The Brisbane memorial began the tradition of memorial tablets to "prominent people".{{sfn|Cable|Clarke|1982|p=15}} The memorial to [[Robert Wardell]] in 1834 rendered "bushranger" into [[Latin]] as "{{lang|la|a latrone vagante occiso}}". Four other monuments were installed between 1830 and 1839. The only memorial on which an indigenous Australian appears is that of [[Edmund Kennedy]]{{Cite sign|title = Memorial plaque to Edmund Beasley Court Kennedy|date = 1849|url = https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:St_James%27_Church,_Sydney_23.JPG|location = North wall, St James' Church, Sydney|publisher = [[Executive Council of New South Wales|Executive Government, Legislative Council of New South Wales]]}} (said to have been "a communicant at St James’"){{cite journal|last=Horsburgh|first=Michael|title=The writing on the wall [St James' Anglican Church, Sydney]|journal=St Mark's Review|date=Winter 1998|issue=174|pages=11–17|url=http://search.informit.com.au/documentSummary;dn=990201798;res=IELAPA|accessdate=6 April 2014|issn=0036-3103}} on whose tablet [[Jackey Jackey]] is remembered. There are memorials to the Macleay family of naturalists, [[Alexander Macleay|Alexander]] and [[William Sharp Macleay]]. {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header_align = center | header = | image1 = St James' Church, Sydney 22.JPG | width1 = 125 | alt1 = Photograph of a marble memorial on a wall with carved fabric draped over it and text on a panel | caption1 = Memorial to [[Alexander Macleay]] | image2 = St James' Church, Sydney 30.JPG | width2 = 125 | alt2 = Photograph of a marble memorial carved with the image of James Brisbane in profile, carved cloth over the top and text on a panel beneath | caption2 = Memorial to Sir [[James Brisbane]] }} The largest single memorial of the 20th century is the [[war memorial]], to the design of [[William Hardy Wilson|Hardy Wilson]], dedicated on 14 June 1922. It commemorates more than 50 men associated with St James' who were killed in the [[First World War]], throughout which the roll of honour was regularly read during the Eucharist.{{sfn|St. James' Church (Sydney, NSW)|1919|p=31}} In 2014, St James' was part of a series of commemorations of the bicentenary of the death of the colony's first [[Governors of New South Wales|Governor]], [[Arthur Phillip]]. On 31 August, a memorial plaque, similar in form to one placed in the nave of Westminster Abbey on 9 July,{{cite web|title=Westminster Abbey honours father of modern Australia|url=http://www.westminster-abbey.org/press/news/2014/july/westminster-abbey-honours-father-of-modern-australia|website=Westminster Abbey|publisher=Westminster Abbey|accessdate=15 July 2014|date=9 July 2014}}{{cite journal|title=Westminster Abbey honours the father of modern Australia|journal=Parish Connections|date=August–September 2014|page=10|url=http://sjks.org.au/wp-content/uploads/Parish-Connections-AugSep14.pdf|accessdate=31 August 2014|publisher=St James' Church, Sydney}} was unveiled by the 37th Governor, [[Marie Bashir]].{{cite journal|title=Arthur Phillip Memorial Service|journal=St James' Parish Connections|date=October–November 2014|pages=12–14|url=http://www.youblisher.com/p/992397-Parish-Connections-October-November-2014|accessdate=24 October 2014|publisher=St James' Church, Sydney}} The church has all its baptismal and marriage registers dating from 1824 to the present day. These were originally handwritten; printed forms came into existence "by government order" in 1826.{{sfn|Cable|Clarke|1982|p=8}} Since it was not compulsory to register births, deaths and marriages until after 1855,{{cite web|title=An Act for registering Births, Deaths, and Marriages 3rd December 1855|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/num_act/ra1855n34191.pdf|work=NSW Legislative Council No. XXXIV|publisher=[[Australasian Legal Information Institute]]|accessdate=12 January 2014}} the records held by St James' are particularly valuable to historians and genealogists and copies are held in the [[National Library of Australia]].Registers of St. James' Anglican Church, King Street, Sydney, N.S.W. [microform], National Library of Australia catalogue records: [http://nla.gov.au/nla.cat-vn6099612 1835–1925]; [http://nla.gov.au/nla.cat-vn6150935 1824–1963], and [http://nla.gov.au/nla.cat-vn6150786 Baptismal register 1854–1924] ===Renovation, restoration, conservation=== {{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | header_align = center | header = | image1 = St James' during alterations 1894.jpg | width1 = 150 | alt1 = An old photo showing the church with a muddy road in the foreground and scaffolding around the spire. | caption1 = St James' with the spire under restoration in 1894 | image2 = St James spire after restoration.JPG | width2 = 151 | alt2 = A detail of the tower and spire showing that it is octagonal and shaped rather like a witch's hat. In this view the copper has been renewed and appears brown and lustrous. On top are a cross and ball with green patina. The tower is brick, has flat corner pilasters and large louvred windows. | caption2 = Spire after a major restoration in 2010 }} Since its erection, the building has undergone significant repair, renovation and conservation, including work on the building fabric, the stained glass windows, the mosaic floors in the chancel and sanctuary and conservation of the Children's Chapel. Major work was done on the interior and the spire in the 1890s and on the crypt in the 1970s.{{sfn|Cable|Clarke|1982|p=50}} The spire was extensively restored from 2008 to 2010, including the tower masonry, the interior framing, the copper covering and the orb and cross.{{cite web |url= http://www.architectureanddesign.com.au/news/industry-news/sydney-s-oldest-church-spire-saved |title=Sydney's oldest church spire saved |publisher=Architecture And Design|date=20 October 2010 |accessdate=17 November 2013}} The spire was rededicated on 20 October 2010.{{cite journal | title=Saving our Spire | last=Annable|first= Rosemary | journal=Parish Connections, the newsletter of St James' King Street |date=July 2009}} The restorations were awarded the [[National Trust of Australia]] Built Heritage Award on 4 April 2011{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/restorers-get-in-touch-with-the-1820s-with-verdigris-and-vertigo-20110404-1cyms.html | title=Restorers get in touch with the 1820s, with verdigris and vertigo | accessdate=6 April 2011 | last=Davey|first= Melissa | date=5 April 2011 | newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|location=Sydney, NSW}} and the [[Australian Institute of Architects|AIA]] Greenway Award for Heritage.{{cite web |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111128050702/http://www.architecture.com.au/i-cms?page=15799 |url=http://www.architecture.com.au/i-cms?page=15799|title=New centres helping young Australians scoop major NSW Architecture Awards |author= Australian Institute of Architects |work=www.architecture.com.au |date= 1 July 2011|archivedate= 28 November 2011|accessdate=17 November 2013}}{{cite web |url= http://www.design5.com.au/stj%20spire.html |publisher=Design 5 – Architects |title= St James' Church Spire |year=2012 |accessdate=17 November 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203014815/http://www.design5.com.au/stj%20spire.html|archivedate=3 December 2013}} [http://www.design5.com.au/pdfs/st%20james%20spire.pdf Restoration project sheet] The jury said that the restoration work showed "consummate care by the architect, the engineer and the builder in conserving the original structure and fabric of the building, improving its strength, performance and waterproofing".{{cite news |title= National accolade for the building blocks of health care| url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/accolade-for-the-building-blocks-of-health-care-20110701-1gv32.html#ixzz1QwC2lLvZ | newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | location=Sydney, NSW| date=2 July 2011 | accessdate=10 July 2011 | last=Davey|first= Melissa}} Restoration continued with work on the church's [[Slate#Slate in buildings|slate]] roof and sandstone perimeter fence. The Spanish slates, installed in the 1970s, proved not to be durable in Sydney's climate due to their high iron content and their poor fixing had resulted in further damage. The solution to the deterioration was to replace the slates using [[Slate industry in Wales|Welsh slates]]. The roof project was completed after a fund-raising effort supported by the National Trust of Australia. In 2013, the interior was repainted after preparation that involved "colour testing and selection, memorial protection and ceiling acoustic repairs".{{cite report|title=Church Wardens' Report | date=March–September 2013 |author=Churchwardens of St James' Church|location=Sydney}} As a heritage-listed building, the church has a program of continual conservation. Its custodians remain "ever mindful" of their responsibility to the wider public as well as to the congregation.{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=23}} ==Worship and ministry== ===Liturgy=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header_align = | header = | image1 = St James Church Sydney lectern.JPG | width1 = 200 | alt1 = The brass lectern is in the traditional form of an eagle and the organ pipes are shown behind it. | caption1 = The eagle lectern (one of two memorials to Canon Allwood) and the [[Pipe organ|organ]] | image2 = St James' Church, Sydney, Stained glass in entrance door adj shadow.JPG | width2 = 150 | alt2 = The image on the glass is of an angel in full frontal with wings outstretched behind and above holding a banner that reads "Praise Ye the Lord" | caption2 = The oldest stained glass in the church (in the entrance door) }} St James' offers three [[Eucharist]]s on Sundays: a Said Eucharist, a Sung Eucharist and a Choral Eucharist. There is a regular [[Evening Prayer (Anglican)|Choral Evensong]] on Wednesdays and one Sunday each month. The Eucharist and other services are also celebrated during the week and the robed choir contributes to its "cathedral style worship".{{sfn|Whiteoak|Scott-Maxwell|2003|p=128}} Festival services are popular and known for their standard of liturgy and music, particularly those services which celebrate high points of the church year such as [[Holy Week]] and Easter, the [[Advent]] carols, the [[Nine Lessons and Carols]], the Christmas Eve Midnight Mass and the patronal festival of St James (son of Zebedee, also known as James the Great) in July. A series of orchestral Masses is held in January.{{cite web|url=http://www.fom.org.au/|title=Friends of Music at St James'|work=fom.org.au|year=2013|accessdate=21 December 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130818021822/http://fom.org.au/|archivedate=18 August 2013|df=dmy-all}} St James' continues to maintain a formal and sacramental liturgy and has weathered the storm of criticism from a diocese with increasingly "[[Low church]]" practices.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=34–41}} It is one of the few Sydney Anglican churches that has upheld the norms of mainstream Anglican tradition, including the use of the [[Stole (vestment)|stole]] by clergy during services, especially during sacraments such as [[baptism]]s and marriages; the [[Book of Common Prayer]] and sacred church music, including the singing of hymns from a [[hymnal]].{{sfn|Porter|2011|pp=10–12}} ===Theology=== The Constitution of the Anglican Church of Australia "commit[s] Anglicans to mainstream Christian orthodoxy", but its ruling principles direct it to that particular tradition within as "represented by the Church of England".{{sfn|Kaye|2002|p=171}} The Australian church had to work out the meaning of its common heritage "in the context of the different cultures of the separate colonies"{{sfn|Kaye|2002|p=170}} but "the way in which that faith pedigree was appealed to and interpreted ... has highlighted differences."{{sfn|Kaye|2002|p=171}} Peter Carnley, former primate of the Anglican Church of Australia, has described Anglicanism's "unique or essential identity" as having "not so much a body of theological teaching, as a style of theological reflection"{{sfn|Carnley|2004|p=81}} that goes back to the Elizabethan theologian [[Richard Hooker]].{{sfn|Frame|2007|p=56}} St James' conforms to this Anglican tradition, part of which is a general dislike of what used to be referred to as 'Enthusiasm': that is, a dislike of "pious individualism and emotional exuberance".This third theological tradition (later called the 'Broad Church' or 'Liberal' tradition) is in addition to those created by the "tensions between Evangelicals and Tractarians". It is one which also "claimed its origins in Richard Hooker's appeal to human reason ... as a rational account of the universe." (Frame (2006) p.56) St James' theological position in the liturgy is evidently consistent with Carnley's explanation that [[Incarnation (Christianity)|incarnational]] reality "might be experienced with the aid of aesthetic, symbolic or sacramental aids to worship."{{sfn|Carnley|2004|pp=70}} Such an adherence to the importance of the sacred and the sublime in worship remains in sharp contradistinction to practice in the surrounding mostly evangelical diocese, which typically eschews beauty and holds to an "ultra-low ecclesiastical aesthetic" that is combined with "ultra-conservative social values".{{cite web|last1=[[Elizabeth Farrelly|Farrelly, Elizabeth]]|title=Sydney Anglicans reject the sacred feminine|url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/sydney-anglicans-reject-the-sacred-feminine-20140604-zrx3t.html|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=5 June 2014|date=4 June 2014}}{{sfn|Lindsay|Scarfe|2012|p=179}} Teaching at St James' takes account of both the Biblical and contemporary historical context.{{cite web|last1=Sempell |first1=Andrew |title=Sermon: "That we may Evermore Live in Him and He in Us" |url=http://sjks.org.au/wp-content/uploads/b-os19-sermon-15.pdf |publisher=St James' Church, Sydney |accessdate=9 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151007010038/http://sjks.org.au/wp-content/uploads/b-os19-sermon-15.pdf |archivedate=7 October 2015 |df= }} In the Sydney diocese, St James's differing view has therefore been controversial since the 19th century as the various rectors led the church towards and away from Anglo-Catholicism.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16898980 |title=St. James' Church |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=NSW |date=1 August 1932 |accessdate=1 July 2014 |page=6 }} Micklem, for example, renewed Anglo-Catholic churchmanship and Davidson "returned it firmly to a moderate position".{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=13,16}} St James' aims to be "an open and inclusive Christian community" that "welcomes all, regardless of age, race, sexual orientation or religion".{{cite web|url=http://sjks.org.au/welcome/|title=Welcome|year=2014|publisher=St James' King Street|accessdate=18 January 2014}} During the long debate in the diocese about the acceptability of [[Ordination of women in the Anglican Diocese of Sydney|women as priests]] and also as preachers, for example, women clergy were welcome. One of the first women ordained as a priest in the Anglican Church in Australia, the Revd Susanna Pain, served as a deacon at St James'{{cite web |url= http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2012/03/07/3447615.htm |title=One for the ladies: 20 years of women's ordination in Australia |first= Eleri|last=Harris|work=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=9 March 2012 |accessdate=17 November 2013|quote=Although Pain was an ordained priest in the [[Anglican Diocese of Canberra and Goulburn|Diocese of Canberra and Goulburn]] at the time, in the Sydney diocese she was only allowed to minister as a deacon, the practical effect of which was that she was not permitted to preside at the Eucharist.}} and women in leadership positions in the Anglican Church such as Bishops [[Kay Goldsworthy]] and [[Genieve Blackwell]], have been invited to preach.{{sfn|Lindsay|Scarfe|2012|p=179}}{{cite news|last=Baird|first=Julia|title=Going backwards into the future|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-opinion/going-backwards-into-the-future-20121130-2am0e.html|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=2 November 2013|date=1 December 2012|location=Sydney, NSW}} The current rector contributes to the public debate about the role and responsibilities of the church in a secularised world{{cite journal|last1=Sempell|first1=Andrew|title=God, Society and Secularism|journal=St Mark's Review|date=September 2012|volume=3|issue=221|pages =56–65}} and in response to statements about same-sex marriage from the Archbishop of Sydney, published a dissenting view.{{cite web|first= Andrew |last=Sempell|url=http://sjks.org.au/wp-content/uploads/Sempell-response-to-redefining-marriage-2.pdf|title=Rector's response to Archbishop regarding redefining marriage|date=20 June 2012|work=St James' Church official website}} ===Congregation=== In the beginning, convicts, soldiers, governors and civil authorities attended the church; in the 21st century, regular patronage by, and programs for, governors, politicians, the legal community and the homeless create a similarly diverse mix. In 1900, such a congregation was described by the sixth rector as representing "many types, many classes. Here we find rich and poor, old and new, the Governor and the Domain loafer, the passing visitor, and the grandchildren of those whose memorial tablets testify to a long connection with the church." William Carr Smith's observation was that "this makes the congregation a difficult one to handle."{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71384721 |title=Restoration of St. James's Church, Sydney|last = Wright| first= Clyde|newspaper=[[Australian Town and Country Journal]]|date=18 August 1900 |accessdate=17 November 2013 |page=37 |publisher=}} Nevertheless, the congregation provides volunteer labour and donates funds for many of church's activities, including laundry work, library administration, flower arrangements, bell ringing, singing in the parish choir and hospitality for the Sister Freda mission. Furnishings for the chapel in the Sydney Hospital were provided by the parishioners during Carr Smith's time, when he became chaplain to the hospital.{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=17}} ===Community service=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header_align = | header = | image1 = Crypt, St James' Church, Sydney.JPG | width1 = 210 | alt1 = View of the crypt from west to east showing the low curved ceiling and the bays created by the junctions of the arches | caption1 = [[Crypt]] | image2 = St James Church, Sydney Children's Chapel Altar.jpg | width2 = 210 | alt2 = View of the Children's Chapel from its doorway with its altar in the centre and the murals on gold walls | caption2 = [[Children's Chapel, St James' Church, Sydney|Children's Chapel]] }} St James' work for the poor, as well as for the city's legal and medical professions, has been continuous from the 19th century. Since early times work "for the poor of the parish"; the promotion of "overseas and inland missions"; liaison with "the city professions in law and medicine" and running "devotional and discussion groups" has been incorporated into the church's mission.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=11}} In the 20th century, the ninth and tenth rectors emphasised "the church's responsibility to society" and encouraged St James' role in the city.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=17}} In the 21st century, these activities have been supplemented by chaplaincy and professional counselling services directed at dealing with the problems associated with the stresses of city life.{{cite web|url=http://sjks.org.au/wp-content/uploads/OUTREACH_Further-information-about-Counselling-at-St-James.pdf|title=Counselling at St James|year=2013|publisher=St James' King Street|accessdate=18 January 2014}} The "most direct part of St James' social welfare work" is the Sister Freda Mission, which began in 1899.{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=17}} Among other things, this ministry provides weekly lunches to the needy and a full dinner at Christmas. Sister Freda (Emily Rich) was a member of the [[Community of the Sisters of the Church]], a religious order which started the Collegiate School in [[Paddington, New South Wales|Paddington]] in 1895. Sister Freda and other members of the order took over the organisation of its mission to the homeless in 1899.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=30}} On Christmas Day in 1901 "about 60 men were entertained at dinner at St James' parish hall, and later in the afternoon 250 unemployed men were treated to tea in the same building by the sisters of the church." After her death in 1936, Sister Freda's name was given to the mission and St James' took over responsibility for its organisation.{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=17}} Since 1954, this service has operated out of the church crypt, relying on donations, including food sourced by [[OzHarvest]], and the efforts of volunteer parishioners. [[File:Supreme Court and St James Church 1842.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.40|Old Supreme Court and St James' Church, showing their proximity. [[John Rae (administrator)|John Rae]] (1842)|alt=Watercolour of St James' next to the Supreme court. The view is looking north along an unpaved road (now Elizabeth Street) on which there are people walking, riding horses and driving carriages. An empty space (now Hyde Park) appears on the right hand side.]] The church's ministry to Sydney's legal fraternity is facilitated by its proximity to buildings used by the profession, including the Law Courts, which is the main building of the [[Supreme Court of New South Wales]] and houses the Sydney registry of the [[High Court of Australia]]; [[The College of Law (Australia)|the College of Law]] and the St James Campus of the [[University of Sydney]], which is the former home of [[Sydney Law School]], still mainly used for legal education by the university.{{cite web |url= http://www.collaw.edu.au/about-us/our-campuses/new-south-wales-sydney-city/ |title= Map of the New South Wales – Sydney City Campus |publisher= College of Law|year=2013|accessdate=21 December 2013}} [[Phillip Street, Sydney|Phillip Street]], which runs north from the church, is home to a large number of [[barristers' chambers]] as well as the [[Law Society of New South Wales]].{{cite web |url= http://www.lawsociety.com.au/ |title=Homepage of the Law Society of NSW |publisher=The Law Society of New South Wales|year=2013 |accessdate=21 December 2013}} Due to this proximity, the church and legal profession have a longstanding relationship, anchored by an annual service to mark the beginning of the [[legal year]] which is attended by judges, solicitors and members of the [[Bar (law)|Bar]] from the [[Supreme Court of New South Wales]] in ceremonial attire.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17656674 |title=Law Term Opens |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=13 February 1940 |accessdate=20 December 2013 |page=9}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27915899 |title=Law Term Opens |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=12 February 1946 |accessdate=20 December 2013 |page=7}}{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=18}} In the 19th century, the relationship was reported in the context of delays to the law and concerns about the need for a suitable set of new courts. In the 20th, it was noted that the "relationship of law and religion" was one of "two co-operating forces, approaching, from different sides, a problem which was common to them both of securing right conduct";{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17316886 |title=Opening of law Term |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=NSW |date=12 February 1936 |accessdate=14 January 2014 |page=9}} and in the 21st century, the Governor still attends special services. Since 1950, there has also been an annual service for the members of the [[Order of St Michael and St George]].{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=18}} ===Education=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header_align = center | header = | image1 = St James' Grammar School (Hall).jpg | width1 = 150 | alt1 = Old photo of the front of the former Hall showing its complex details. It was built of brick with a rusticated basement, balconies with curved wrought iron balustrades, a large entrance stairway under a prominent pediment and Art Nouveau panels. | caption1 = St James' [[Church hall|Parish Hall]] (designed by Burcham Clamp, dedicated 1903, demolished 1961, replaced 1963) | image2 = St James' School stone fragment.jpg | width2 = 150 | alt2 = A weathered stone triangular building fragment with a worn carved inscription. | caption2 = Fragment from St James' School.
The inscription reads:
Saint James's Grammar School Erected A:D: MDCCCXL [1840] William Grant Broughton D.D. Bishop of Australia }} In the 19th century, religious denominations made a major contribution to education at all levels before this was taken over by the state. From its beginnings, St James' was involved in education for both children and adults. Richard Hill, the first minister, "began Australia's first kindergarten and [[William Timothy Cape|William Cape]] managed a school based on new educational principles".{{sfn|Judd|Cable|2000|page=14}}{{cite web|last=Goodin|first=V. W. E.|title=Cape, William Timothy (1806–1863)|url=http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A010552b.htm|work=[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]|volume=1|publisher=[[Melbourne University Press]]|accessdate=18 December 2013|pages=209–210|year=1966}} Hill worked with the [[Benevolent Society]], the [[Bible society|Bible Society]], [[Aboriginal Australians|Aboriginals]], the [[Sydney Hospital|Hospital]], "various convict establishments and a range of schools," including [[Industrial School]]s.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=30}} By 1823 Greenway's school building had been erected in [[Elizabeth Street, Sydney|Elizabeth Street]] and the principal St James' School was situated there until 1882, becoming the Anglican "normal" school with more than 600 students and a range of experienced teachers.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=36}} In secondary education, a Sydney branch of the [[The King's School, Parramatta|King's School]] operated briefly in the Greenway building and Bishop Broughton operated the St James' Grammar School in a building erected in [[Phillip Street, Sydney|Phillip Street]]. The Grammar School, presided over by the Revd C. Kemp was described as "of inestimable value to the then youth of the colony". Bishop Broughton also set up St James' College to provide tertiary education for secular students as well as to prepare students for [[ordination]]. The St James' School closed in 1882 and the government resumed the Greenway building.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=36}} Tuition for the students of [[St Paul's College, University of Sydney]] was originally provided in the vestry of St James'.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=36}} In the 20th century, St James' developed its education program for children and adults and continued them in the 21st century.{{cite web|url=http://sjks.org.au/education/|title=Education|publisher=St James' King Street|year=2014|accessdate=12 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114141725/http://sjks.org.au/education/|archivedate=14 January 2014|df=dmy-all}} A Sunday school for children is held in the crypt. Educational activities for adults are offered through the St James' Institute which provides a range of programs open to all to explore the Christian faith and engage in debate about contemporary issues from a theological perspective.{{cite web|url=http://sjks.org.au/education/st-james-institute/|title=St James' Institute|publisher=St James' King Street|year=2014|accessdate=12 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114141732/http://sjks.org.au/education/st-james-institute/|archivedate=14 January 2014|df=dmy-all}} For example, in 2012, the Institute hosted a seminar on "Women in the Australian Church: Untold Stories" in conjunction with the International Women's Network and [[Movement for the Ordination of Women|MOWatch]].{{cite web|title=Twentieth anniversary events 10 MAY - Sydney 'Women in the Australian Church: the Untold Stories'|url=http://www.mowatch.org.au/simplified/women_priests.html|publisher=MOWatch|accessdate=6 March 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140126124546/http://www.mowatch.org.au/simplified/women_priests.html|archive-date=26 January 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}St James' Institute 2012 Program pp. 10–11 In 2013, there was a meeting of "deans and ministers from Anglican churches that serve the business districts in major cities around world" to discuss the churches' response to the [[Financial crisis of 2007–08|Global Financial Crisis]].{{cite web|last= Andrew West (presenter)|title=The church and corporate greed|url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/religionandethicsreport/the-church-and-corporate-greed/3958478|publisher=[[Radio National]]|accessdate=7 November 2013|date=18 April 2012}} ===Past and present clergy=== The Reverend [[Samuel Marsden]] delivered the first sermon on 6 July 1824.{{cite web|url=http://www.sl.nsw.gov.au/discover_collections/history_nation/religion/places/churchgallery.html|title=The Court House & St James Church, Hyde Park Sydney, 1839 pencil drawing by Thomas Hatfield (SSV1/ Pub Ct H/2)|publisher=State Library of New South Wales|work=Gallery of Churches|year=2013|accessdate=17 November 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103114114/http://www.sl.nsw.gov.au/discover_collections/history_nation/religion/places/churchgallery.html|archive-date=3 November 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In 1836 the first (and only) Bishop of Australia, William Grant Broughton, was installed at St James' as there was still no cathedral. Broughton regularly officiated at St James' as at the first ordination of an Anglican priest in Australia (the Revd T. Sharpe) on 17 December 1836.{{sfn|The Church|1944|p=6}} [[File:St James rector.jpg|thumb|upright=1.50|alt = Black and white photo of the rector in black clerical garb striding across the footpath towards Phillip Street|The 16th rector in [[King Street, Sydney|King Street]] outside the church (2014)]] The [[rector (ecclesiastical)|rector]] of St James' is assisted by associate rectors (it was not until the 1890s that the title "rector" was used).{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=9}}{{sfn|The Church|1963|p=10}} The current (sixteenth) rector is the Reverend Andrew Sempell and the associate rector is the Reverend John Stewart.{{cite web|title=Clergy: The Reverend Andrew Sempell|url=http://sjks.org.au/welcome/clergy/|publisher=St James' King Street|accessdate=19 December 2013}}{{cite news|title=Dean takes on new challenge|url=http://www.centralwesterndaily.com.au/story/780515/dean-takes-on-new-challenge/|accessdate=19 December 2013|newspaper=[[Central Western Daily]]|date=15 March 2010}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * 1824–1836 [[Richard Hill (priest)|Richard Hill]] * 1836–1838 Robert Cartwright * 1838–1840 George Napoleon Woodd * 1840–1884 [[Robert Allwood]] * 1885–1895 Henry Latimer Jackson * 1896–1910 [[William Carr Smith]] * 1910–1916 W.F. Wentworth-Sheilds"Francis was to sign his name as Wentworth-Sheilds."{{cite web|last=Cable|first=K.J.|title=Wentworth-Shields, Wentworth Francis (1867–1944)|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/wentworth-shields-wentworth-francis-9047/text15939,|work=Australian Dictionary of Biography|publisher=National Centre of Biography, Australian National University|accessdate=21 December 2013|volume=12|year=1990}} * 1917–1937 [[Philip Arthur Micklem]] * 1938–1955 Edwin John Davidson * 1956–1962 William John Edwards * 1962–1975 Frank Leslie Cuttriss * 1976–1983 Howard Charles Hollis * 1984–1997 Peter John Hughes * 1997–2001 [[Richard Hurford]] * 2001–2009 Peter Walter Kurti * 2010–present Andrew John Sempell {{Div col end}} ==Music== St James' has had a strong musical and choral tradition "integral" to its liturgies since the 1820s and is known both for the high standard of the [[Church music|sacred music]] as well as for its regular public recitals and concerts.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=24}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14095369 |title=St. James' Church |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=26 July 1897 |accessdate=8 October 2011 |page=9}} St James' has a choir, a fine three-manual [[pipe organ]] and a peal of bells hung for [[change ringing]]. [[Isaac Nathan]], who "constituted himself musical laureate to the colony"{{cite web | url = http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/nathan-isaac-2502/text3377|title = 'Nathan, Isaac (1790–1864)'|accessdate = 17 January 2014 | author = Catherine Mackerras | year = 1967|work = Australian Dictionary of Biography, National Centre of Biography| publisher = Australian National University}} and is considered "Australia's first composer", created a musical society at St James' in the 1840s.{{cite web | url = http://www.dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/nathan_isaac | title = Nathan, Isaac | accessdate = 17 January 2014 | author = Graeme Skinner | year = 2008 | work = Dictionary of Sydney | publisher = Dictionary of Sydney Trust}} ===Organ=== The original organ, installed in the west gallery, was built by John Gray of London and was played for the first time on 7 October 1827. It received the following praise in the colonial newspaper [[The Australian (1824 newspaper)|''The Australian'']]. {{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | header_align = center | header = | image1 = St James' Church, Sydney organ (1931).jpg | width1 = 178 | alt1 = alt=A black and white photo of a man playing the organ showing the keyboard and the pedals | caption1 = Organists Mr Field (1931) | image2 = Organist Alistair Nelson.JPG | width2 = 123 | alt2 = Colour photograph of smiling organist in red and white vestments playing the St James' organ. The sheet music, keyboard and some of the organ stops are visible. | caption2 = and Alistair Nelson (2014) }}
''"St. James's new organ pealed its notes of praise for the first time at noon service on Sunday, to an overflowing congregation, more numerous perhaps than any congregation St. James's had ever before witnessed. The organ was not in perfect harmony, owing, in a great measure, to its yet incomplete state. Its intonations, however, in many instances, was full, rich, and harmonious, and those of the congregation were not a few who felt its tones swell on the ear like the welcome voice of a long parted friend!"''{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article37072595 |title=No title |newspaper=[[The Australian]]|date=10 October 1827 |accessdate=31 August 2013 |page=2 }}
The organ was modernised and enlarged in the 1870s by William Davidson. After a number of moves around the galleries, it was placed in what had been intended as the south porch. At the time the church's interior was reconstructed at the turn of the 20th century, it was positioned on either side of the chancel platform at the eastern end where it remains.{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|pp=24–25}} Organ specialists Hill, Norman & Beard (Aust) Pty Ltd gave the organ a major refurbishment and reconstruction between 1970 and 1971 at a cost of $35,000.{{cite web | url = http://www.dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/st_james_anglican_church_queens_square | title = St James Anglican church Queens Square | accessdate = 17 January 2014 | author = Mark Dunn | year = 2008 | work = Dictionary of Sydney | publisher = Dictionary of Sydney Trust}} [[File:Nunc dimittis.jpg|thumb|upright|alt= Printed cover page of musical score, using different fonts and "Respectfully dedicated to the Revd. R. Allwood, B.A., incumbent of St. James' and Canon of the cathedral church of St. Andrew", for use in a service at St Andrew's| ''Nunc dimittis'' by organist and choir master, James Furley]] ===Choir=== St James' has had a choir since early colonial times. James Pearson accepted the office of choir leader in 1827 and arranged some of the music that was sung.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article31758255 |title=No Title|newspaper=[[The Monitor (Sydney, NSW)|The Monitor]]|date=9 March 1827 |accessdate=8 January 2014 |page=8}}{{cite web|last=Skinner|first=Graeme|title=A chronological checklist of colonial Australian musical compositions, arrangements, and transcriptions c. 1788–1840|url=http://www.graemeskinner.id.au/checklist1788-1840.htm|work=Austral Harmony Music and musicians in colonial Australia|accessdate=10 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110090933/http://www.graemeskinner.id.au/checklist1788-1840.htm|archivedate=10 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}{{sfn|Bebbington|1997|p=120}} He also offered to teach "a few steady persons, of either sex," if they would volunteer to join the choir.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2192937 |title=Tristan d'Acunha |newspaper=[[The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser|The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser (NSW: 1803–1842)]] |date=21 July 1829 |accessdate=8 January 2014 |page=2 }} In those early days, the choir was a "mixed one, of male and female voices, some of them professional", but by the end of the 19th century, the choristers were all males. Until Anthony Jennings was appointed Director of Music in 1995, the choirmaster was also the organist.{{sfn|Drummond|1978|p=53}}{{sfn|Cable|Annable|1999|p=25}} Some choirmasters, such as James Furley, also composed original works for the choir.{{cite web|last=Furley|first=James|title=Nunc dimittis|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.mus-vn5715925|work=Composition for St James' choir|publisher=J. R. Clarke (music publisher)|year=c. 1870|accessdate=14 January 2014}} [[Arthur J. Mason]] served 1898–1907 (and was City Organist 1901–1907),{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14342860 |title=Church News |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=9 January 1901 |accessdate=8 January 2014 |page=5}} was succeeded by George Faunce Allman in the role.{{sfn|Cable|Clarke|1982|p=40}} The current choir is composed of about a dozen semi-professional adults. They sing on Sundays at the 11.00 am Choral Eucharist, Wednesdays at the 6:15 pm Choral Evensong, monthly at the 3.00 pm Choral Evensong held on the last Sunday of the month, as well as at a number of midweek [[Calendar of saints (Church of England)|feast days]] held during the year. In January, during the summer holiday period, St James' presents three full orchestral Masses during which [[liturgical music]] by composers such as [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]], [[Joseph Haydn|Haydn]] and [[Franz Schubert|Schubert]] is used for its original purpose and incorporated into the service. On these occasions, the choir is joined by a small orchestra.{{cite web|url=http://sjks.org.au/orchestral-masses-2014/|title=Orchestral masses|year=2014|publisher=St James' King Street|accessdate=18 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114141840/http://sjks.org.au/orchestral-masses-2014/|archivedate=14 January 2014|df=dmy-all}} [[File:St James' Church, Sydney 44 brighter.jpg|thumb|left|upright= 1.60|alt=A photo of a red-robed choir in the chancel with the altar behind them. Candles and a brass cross are on the altar and the choirmaster is facing the singers with his back to the camera|The [[choir]] performing during a subscription series (2013)]] On occasion, the St James' choir has combined with other choirs,{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17001219 |title=Combined choirs |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=25 August 1933 |accessdate=13 January 2014 |page=4}} such as when it joined the Sydney Philharmonia Motet Choir{{sfn|Pleskun|2012|p=580}} or the choir of St Mary's Cathedral to present [[Vespro della Beata Vergine 1610|Monteverdi's Vespers]] in 2013.
